content:
Posted: January 7
												This is mainly a single player game with some multiplayer features sprinkled on top. Unfortunately, it requires a constant internet connection for you to play, ostensibly to cater to this multiplayer element and to make the game "better for you" (if you do a quick google search you'll find this answer from Ubisoft on a number of forums). To me, though, it smells a little bit more of DRM. If your internet goes down (or their servers, which is not uncommon enough) you are locked out of your own game. Somehow, I'm having a hard time seeing how this makes Steep a better experience for me. It seems like not being able to play at all is a little bit worse than being able to play without real-time online challenge updates.Oh, and you also need to download Uplay and launch it through that, because apparently the way almost all other games launch is not a perfectly reasonable way for a game to launch. Better to force another client on people who willingly gave you some money for your game.The game is good, but I'm requesting a refund because Ubisoft are awful.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 28
												A beautiful game. Good atmosphere. Definitely has the replay value and is hopefully a good sign of change for Ubisoft. Even if the story is probably the most skippable story I've ever had to play through.I would definitely say that this game is good value for money, which is a rare statement nowerdays especially for myself who has been dissapointed with the gaming industry for the past few years, and Ubisoft has played a big part in my dwindling confidence with the gaming industry.Steep is flawed though, as to be expected by a game from Ubisoft, but these flaws do not apply to every aspect of the game and so do not completely ruin it!The almost gamebreaking camera plagues your every step, making it sometimes impossible to clearly see your path and definitely takes you away from the experience. The way your character interacts with the enviroment is inconsistant and is littered with tweening issues, bugs and glitches. I've discovered that all the issues ive had with the way my character travels around is due to the fact that the game keeps your board flat even if youre on a slope, which means if youre on an uneven surface your character doesnt try to adjust to the changes but simple stays static which leads to the many soul destroying crashes we all have to put up with.The scoring is unfair and is mostly based on luck, last night i just did the same trick for two hours, never getting the same score twice and the scores i did recieve did not reflect what had happened on the screen. Sometimes poorly executed tricks out perform well performed tricks and visa versa. I believe every player has had that moment where they have performed an amazing trick only to be given a +150. Then a while later your character spazzes out on a rock and youre given a score of +3200! In order to play this game you have to suspect disbelief and just wait for the good scores to come.The crashes - Yes...ive messed up. But does my character have to ragdoll down the whole mountain before i can start having fun again? A lot of the time its easier to just retry the event than wait for your character to stop ragdollingStory - ergh. characters - -vomits- Mountain Stories - jesus christ burn them with fire.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												After 10-20 hours of playing, I was going to give Steep a bad review but then everything changed (except for my underwear).The first thing you'll notice is that Steep is visually stunning (like me). It's easy to pick up (also like me) but when it comes to performing like a pro and knowing how best to get the most out of it, it's badly lacking in instructions or tips. Granted this may be because I'm stupid, but it took me longer than usual to figure out why I couldn't land tricks and do other stuff. Also the menu is rather unintuitive and seems to be filled with useless information (like me) that I don't have any interest in.That said, once I figured it all out and had spent enough time exploring the slopes, the enjoyment increased dramatically. By this time I had unlocked more locations and the courses became far more intense and challenging. All of a sudden I was getting nearly more air than what's between my ears and I also began to find locations that I could make a course/challenge out of. The speed you get on the steepest slopes is exhilarating and the slightest mistake will have you crashing like my mum on a motorbike. The wingsuit had also gone from getting into a starfish position and falling, to zooming through tricky rock canyons and caves that are destined to give you more brain injuries than what I’ve accumulated in real life from riding on the back of my mum’s motorbike.Paragliding has still yet to excite me but it is useful for exploring, especially as it can climb up when you get some wind under you and I kinda like the exploration element of the game. The narration during parts of the game tries to be cool but is pretty dull (like me once again) but totally makes up for it in the fashion stakes by offering numerous jackets in pink, though I would’ve liked to have seen 1-piece lycra bodysuits like they wear at the Winter Olympics. I like lycra.I could name a number of bugs, issues and things that should've been in the game but for $40au (on sale) I’m more than happy with my purchase.★★★★★★★★★✰

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I REALLY wanted to like this game. I'm not having any issues running it and it looks gorgeous. I can't tell you how excited I was when I heard about Steep. I loved Skate and completed every challenge in the game, and spent hours just free skating and making lines. I'm a bigger fan of snowboarding though and I haven't gotten into a snowboarding game since SSX tricky, which was arcady and completely unrealistic. So I was really looking forward to a more realistic snowboard game, where I could just throw on tunes and go crazy on the mountain. Steep is EXACTLY that, and I was ready to start sinking days into it. I got through the tutorial and started exploring the mountain, found a run I wanted to do and away I went.The controls though... my god... they just don't respond in a way that lets you feel like your character has any sort of flow.The timing just feels very off to put it plainly. You need to jump pretty early in comparison to any other skate/snowboard games, which is awkward at first, but forgivable once you get the hang of it. You use the LS to either flip or spin your character and LT or RT + RS for grabbing and tweaking. The grabbing works fine but the spins and flips seem to only work half the time I want them to. Theres a bit of a sweet spot just as you leave your jump to start a good spin or flip. The landing is where I gave up though. Even if I look like I'm coming into it perfectly, I bail more often than not. The whole experience made me feel more frustrated trying to get my character to do what I want, and land a regular jump FFS, rather than feeling awesome pulling off sweet tricks. Maybe i'm missing something, but it was enough that I uninstalled it. Hope they tweak the controls, it's close to being the perfect snowboard game. But right now I find it more frustrating than fun.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1
												When I first found out about Steep, I was very excited because to me it looked like the hybridization of SSX: On Tour and Skate 3. And for the first two hours of the game, that's exactly what I got, however after that mark it rapidly declines in the key element rarely seen in Ubisoft games known as "fun". Visually, it's gorgeous, there's no arguing that. The way the snow sparkles under certain lighting conditions is wonderful, and the sound design as well is top notch. However, regarding gameplay, Ubisoft for some inane reason decided to take a sports game where you run around wearing an elk head while plowing through evil talking snowmen on your '90s dixie cup themed snowboard VERY realistic controls and trick physics. There is absolutely zero way to correct or change your rotation midair, often times landing is completely RNG which forces the player to restart races again and again and again and AGAIN for sometimes up to an hour. In a game as cosmetically goofy with tasks as ridiculous as some of the ones in game are, one would expect a control/trick scheme to be that of SSX or Skate no? Where you can string together multiple ridiculously impossible moves that defy all laws of physics? This game does not have that. None of it. It has the visuals of those older extreme sports games, but none of the gameplay. Crashing is punishing and frustrating, to the point where it makes you not want to do the trick based races after having the game ♥♥♥♥ you over so badly so many times in a row.Don't believe me and still want to try it out? Wait for a deep sale at the very least. One of my friends got this for me for Christmas because I had been talking about it for a while, and honestly I feel bad for that friend because his good intentions ended up getting wasted all because of poor marketing on Ubisofts part.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												This game is bad. The UI is impossible to comprehend. The controls— once you've mastered the very unconventional layout (and good luck, after the laughably shallow tutorial)— just flat-out don't work sometimes. The challenges become less about skill and instead about trying and re-trying until you finally complete a run in which the game actually responds to every input successfully.The laws of physics, too, seem to have been described to the programmers over the phone while on a crowded bus. I've lost count of how many times my character has built up speed by whizzing down a mountain only to come to a screeching halt atop the smoothest ramp in the Alps and stumbling uselessly off the lip.The snow is quite pretty, though, and you'll get plenty of time to admire it as the camera makes a point of aiming just low enough to ensure you've no idea of the precise moment to jump, then laughing in your stupid face as you bounce gracelessly down the cliff you couldn't see coming.If you're looking for a fun, challenging (for the right reasons), rewarding snow-sports game, I reccomend SSX.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												The graphics are great, the map itself is most of the time something else, so its not repeating itself. It might look like its about the same every mountain, but it is not, while the challenges / quests are most of the time similiar (reach that point in this amount of time, score that much points etc.) the routes of the challenges is always something else. For my choice I like the Bones - Challenges the most fun. After about 1 day of gaming, I reached level 25 (max level) and rechead "Legend" in Freestyle, because I believe it is the easiest. The game is openworld, and you can change everywhere you like, but not on the run, so you have to get to a stop.What I dont like: The spawns of you character. If you travel to a Challenge by "Mountain view" I sometimes found myself on top of the location, where you used to spawn, like on a rock. But even more depressing is it, if you set yourself a spawn, and then try again and end up being teleported 1 Meter downwards in the ground, so you see the entire map from underground. Sometimes you can just fly out or ski out, but can't walk out which is really annoying. If you are in a group you don't just go for Gold, but try to get the higher score than your mates, so its much more fun and is more time consuming. Would I buy it again?- Probably, but its not made for everyone, some got other expectations. Was it fun? - Hell yeah.Will I be playing it more? - Only with some friends, even though I haven't got every character maxed out.Is this review too long?- Probably yes, sorry for bad english :)

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31
												Back in the day I was a big fan of the Tony Hawk Series up until THUG2, and a played many snowboarding games mainly the SSX series. What Steep does is roughly the same idea but on a grander scale. Many will find this game to be reptitive, and that could be a similar thing said about Dynasty Warriors, but in saying this that describes the kinds of fanbases and what the game is offering. Steep offers a sandbox experience in which you can travel across an entire peak without load zones and compete in time trials, challenges or play amongst the various story missions. You have the options of Snowboarding, Skiing, Paragliding and Wingsuit/Sky Diving. The charm of the game comes from it's gameplay, IF YOU DO NOT LIKE THIS KIND OF GAMEPLAY, then I 110% recommend you do not buy this game, it will get boring quick. Although if you are a fan of the aforementioned sports games then I fully recommend this game.Performance wise, since the engine is rendering mostly snow and terrain LOD the game does run fairly well, I still would recommend having a decent setup as any thing below 60fps will turn anyone off on a fast paced xtreme sports game such as this.Graphically I would assume its a similar engine to other Ubisoft games but I have not done extensive research in this.Base game content isn't sparse although since it is a sandbox some of that comes down to the player also. With upcoming season pass content but also free content updates with an free Alaska peak DLC, I would say you are looking at a minimum 50 hours of content to muck around with until the DLC drops. Leveling up your main skill level will liekly be a quick experience [depends on your apptitude] but levelling up the various sub categories to the game will take some time.Live events are included also.8/10

content:

												SO, i loved "snow" and i thought to myself. Gee this is a uplay game not some random dev.surely it has to be good. and for the most part it is.HOWEVER there are a MULTITUDE of problems i ran into within the first hour. overall the game is well optimized and operates well. but for me, ill stick to "snow"The problems i have with it are as follows.1. its overpriced2. i ran into a fair few collision issues on some ramps.3. its seem to be WAY more about the challenges than ANY kind of free roam.3. (extended) i was free roaming and after about 5 ish minuets i got "you have reached the border of the map" and it made me restart. This happened 5 times. everytime i tried to make a long-ish run.4. a strange lack of pricision. you tell your character what to do and he does it on his own. I could not tell him to keep spinning or stop spinning. he just decided when he wanted to stop. and more often than not it was backwards (skiing).5. ANYTIME you touch a rock, for ANY reason. you take damage.6. the little wood ramps and Roofs just STOP you like a ROCK.7. the air physics feel OFF. you can speed up hardly at ALL on the parachute. and the wingsuit just feels like 3 settings, Dont fall vertically, fall vertically, and fall vertically faster. none of them felt like it slowed me down or sped me up at all.8. You have 0 control on ice.You can stop no problem, but anything else is a NO. I HAVE SKI POLES PUSHING ME FORWARD. and im sliding completly sideways. 9. I just felt stuck to the ground unless you press jump. otherwise you never leave the ground. little ridges in the snow? NOPE magnet feet. In the end im just not that impressed with it at all.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												So I played about an hour of the game and to be honest there's not much game here.Steep is an open world winter sports game developed by Ubisoft Annecy. It’s got a pretty cool concept in that you travel around a big mountain range finding new routes to do races or points trials in 4 different sports, snowboarding, skiing, wingsuit flying and paragliding. You can compete with friends to get high scores and medals and stuff and that’s about it really. Unfortunately after about half an hour it really wore thin on me and for £40 there’s just nowhere near enough content to justify a purchase.On the plus side it looks ♥♥♥♥ing awesome with snow reacting to you walking through it the draw distances are really impressive and it has a solid sountrack too. Performance is also top notch, no frame drops at all. You do get people yelling cringy♥♥♥♥♥♥though, stuff like “this is living” when snowboarding down a mountain, might as well get them to say “radical dude” or something. The controls were a bit unresponsive as well and the scoring system makes no sense, this main video is me getting a gold on a challenge despite messing up every attempt at a trick. Good job Ubisoft.Can’t recommend it, if it gets some DLC to flesh it out it could be fun but £40 for this is pretty crappy value for money. 3/7 no bobsleighing.If you want to watch my review on YouTube you can here: It's only a minute long!

content:
Posted: January 24
												Great game if you're into the extreme sports stuff but it has its flaws for sure. Before I get to the bad, let me emphasize that this really is a nice snowboarding/skiing game, with a little bit of flight as well. The mountains are beautiful, there's a lot of diversity between mountain ranges as far as rockiness/'steep'ness go, the challenges can be pretty fun, and the multiplayer isn't THAT dead. Not to mention very nice customization. But, as for the drawbacks, - soundtrack is okay but there's maybe a total of 20 songs, that you'll be hearing over and over again. - mechanics can be a little buggy at times, though overall they aren't bad. Just expect to get hung up and flung around ridiculously sometimes when you hit slopes sideways or the edges of rocks. - controls for keyboard are fine. I have 99% of my playtime on it and can't complain. I plugged in a Steam controller and Xbox just for the sake of this review, and while the Steam controller is pretty good the Xbox controller is fantastic for this game, almost makes me wish I had been using it all along. Very well integrated. However, if you get used to keyboard you aren't losing out by not having one.- Only took me about 24 hours to 100% all challenges w/gold medals and get all drop zones. There is a lot of replayability, though, and it feels like a lot more content than 24 hours makes it sound. I give this game a thumbs up, but consider some of the other things you could do with $60 before purchasing.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Steep is a game that I had high expectations for. As a kid I loved to ski and still do, nothing beats looking down a snowy white mountain with snow hitting your face. The feeling is like nothing else in the world, a feeling like at any point everything can go wrong but it doesn't. When you go down the mountain your making art, your trail is your trail and can never be fully replicated. Steep nails this feeling perfectly. The world is beautiful and gives you the freedom of creating your own lines and doesn't force you on a set pathway. The ski/snowboard physics are very good and but there is one gripe I have with them and thats the way they interact when on rocks. The game plays it off as it being impossible to have control on any rock surface which can really ruin a great run. The challanges themselves are all very fun except for the paragliding ones. I rarely got frustrated while playing except when I had to paraglide up the Matterhorn. Even though I still got Gold it was one of the few times during the game where I didn't want to continue, ddn't want to explore the next slope or challange ahead of me. Some say this game is light on content but I truely dissagree. On paper this isn't on $60 dollar game but when you break it down and actually understand the range of things you can do it's unbeliable. The soundtrack is amazing at times and irritating occasionally as well but I found that most songs were enjoyable to listen to even though they are almost all liscenced music. A common misconception with this game is that it's the next SFX or tony hawk pro skater with a snowboard. That's not true, it's more of a mix of a simmulator and if Skate was a winter sports game. I very much do recomend Steep at it's launch price tag since it's a game that has more under the initial layer that you just need to find. Find the perfect slope and racing down wiith friends or other online players is insanely fun. I expect to continue playing this for a while and I can't wait to see what more it has in store.8.5/10 -Infinite

												I dont ever write reviews but had to say my piece on this game. I have owned the game about a week and have put 16 hours in, everytime i turn on my pc steep is the first game i want to play, its amazing!I'm not a big snowboarding fan i have never done it in my life though i did love ssx and cool boarders (for you old school guys out there) so for anyone that likes the idea of snowboarding, skiing, wing suit jumping, paragliding, this game is for you.I had read reviews saying that the game wasn't worth the price so i waited for the christmas sales and got it then, but honestly if i knew how good the game was i would have bought it for the full price without hesitation.it's open world and the map is huge, and there are so many missions and things to do, weather you want to free roam and make your own trails (which can then be saved and shared with friends) or to do all the main and side missions.The game has a couple of bugs which can be expected for a new game and none are by any means game breaking just minor menu glitches and things like that.The game can be frustrating at times for you guys like me that wish to get gold in every mission, as some are really difficult and takes a hell of a lot of attempts, i'm level 20 so far and have made gold in each event so keep at it!Highly rate the game and with dlc's and extra content that will be released it's only going to get better. And the graphics are amazing!!!!If anyone out there is in 2 minds about getting it i recommend you do, you wont regret it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												This is going to be a review of great length, of mixed feelings, of ups and downs, and of hopefulness. It will go chronologically from the beginning to the end (at the time of posting) of my experience with the game.First off, I have snowboarded for a good portion of my life. I started more than 5 years ago and have loved it ever since. I've snowboarded in Utah and Colorado every year since I first experience how fun winter sports are. In terms of this game, I've played it during two of its private testing phases, as well as the final public testing phase. Although I only have 11 hours in the game at this time, in reality I have played steep more than double that amount of time. I have gold-medaled almost every challenge on almost every mountain except the Matterhorn and Mont Blanc, and you will soon discover why this is the case. Originally I intended on reviewing this game after gold-medaling all of the challenges, but I was tomahawking down the Matterhorn when I realized that it was time.Now, to the review.The tutorial is fine. Having played the game before, I was annoyed that it was mandatory, but it ended with relative swiftness and I was able to be on my way. It was useful for the uninformed, and fast enough not to discourage those that know what they're up to. The first locations I played around in were the lower mountains. These are my favorite places to play this game. The physics and controls (ironically) work best in areas of less steep terrain. The game is relaxing, the lighting is beautiful, and it's a playground for skiing and snowboarding. PIllow fields are fun to jump around in, there are alpine forests to hike through on foot or shoot through on snowboard/skis. Around the peaks you can find wonderful routes to paraglide, and you can wingsuit through trees and powerlines for an adrenaline rush. There are plenty of cliffs to ski down and plenty of rooftops to jump off of. I even managed to jib a tree, which honestly might be my personal favorite accomplishment so far in my experience with the game. I love the lower mountains because they are enjoyable. After sufficiently leveling up to gain access to the more "challenging" (but in actuality more frustrating) mountains, I had my foray in those as well. Peak of the damned was difficult, but I enjoyed myself for the most part. I damned some of the challenges for reasons I will soon mention. One of my first (minor) gripes with this game was noticed here. Some of the challenges you do reset your ambiance (basically, the lighting and mood of the game world) to what seems to be a predetermined mode. This is annoying and cannot be tampered with. Giving the player the power to change the ambiance of the game and then wresting that control from them at certain points in the game is something I would like to be able to opt out of. The Matterhorn is where my feelings for this game take a turn. The Matterhorn is the epitome of the difference between something that is HARD and something that is CHALLENGING. Peak of the Damned was challenging for me. I had plenty of goes at the challenges before I got gold, but I never felt like they were impossible (save one challenge that, in hindsight, was foreshadowing of what was to come). On the other hand (or ski), the Matterhorn was simply hard. The challenges given to you are nigh-impossible. I don't say that because I couldn't do them. I gold-medaled a good portion of them; however, I did so after crashing over and over, hiking up the mountain to reach checkpoints, and skiing down when I could.The Matterhorn is supposed to be extreme, but I don't believe it's designed to frustrate you. I don't believe it would frustrate you if the game played as the game should play. Ah, the meat and potatoes of the argument. The game does not function as it should.Rocks are like lava. If you run into a rock going 40 mph, of course you should crumble. That's realistic. What isn't realistic (and is instead extremely frustrating) is wiping out because you skiied over a 15 foot stretch of smooth rock/ice on the face of a mountain, and your knees gave out like they were remotely detonated. Switching direction of travel requires two thumbsticks to be pushed in opposite directions. Why is it, then, that as I slide down the side of the Matterhorn Jeremy-Jones style so as not to crash, with the left thumbstick pointing back and the right thumbstick untouched, that my rider decides to change direction?Winguiting is fun as all hell. Nothing is wrong with it. Paragliding is fun as all hell. Nothing is wrong with it. I'm sure I could play another hour of the game and encounter more of my forgotten gripes with this game, but I think I've made a point. The game has SO much potential. It's already the best game on PC that has ever been made in the snowsports genre. If the phyics are fixed, the G-force system is rewired, and unrealistic ways of dealing with real-world occurences are done away with, this game will kick♥♥♥♥♥ I'll still be playing the game after this review is published, but I'm going to spend a lot less time on the more harsh mountains. They would be fun if the game was built to handle them, but untill all of the game mechanics are fixed to allow CHALLENGING descents on the harsher mountains, not FRUSTRATING ones, I'll be spending my time cruising through some low-elevation powder. If there's anything in this review that I seem to have missed and/or totally screwed up on, please notify me so I can take care of it.TL;DR: If you want to cruise through powder, fly adrenaline-pumping wingsuit routes, and enjoy the beauty of the mountains, buy the game on sale. It's the best there is at the moment. If you're looking to descend mountains that no one would descend in real life, I wouldn't recommend it. You won't want to descend them in-game either.

Posted: December 19, 2016
												I am enjoying the game so far. Cool things I like about this game:-Online multiplayer is very smooth, which is fairly uncommon in most games these days. Very slick partying up-If you are creative, there are a bunch of crazy lines for the four base sports(sking, boarding, wingsuit, paragliding-Moving around the mountain is just a press of a button, no load times :)-Satisfaction at a smooth run/drop-Replay function looks good-You can spectate people you are in a group with! That is fun, to watch them attempt stuff on your challengeCool things my buddy and I have done in online play:-Skiing down a hill, we spot a lookout point. Unlock it and instantly spawn there so we can paraglide across a lake to a little cottage overlooking a biiiig drop. Proceed to wingsuit drop from the edge of the cottage, scraping our feet on the take-off, and whip out a challenge which my friend scored big on(I biffed a lot)-Spawned most of the up the big peak, and then went on a hike up the ridge to the most summity summit in the game, and used that as a drop point for all the sports.-Scoot down a hill taking turns setting the line, and stumble across the mother of all wingsuit drops, through a series of tunnels, mostly straight downBefore you buy:-DLC includes game content, including new sports. That is a serious bummerd-Controls are not like SSX Tricky, and the tricks/speed are sorta realistic

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												First my specs:My old rig still runs even the latest games extremely well.Nvidia GeForce GTX 760Intel Core i7 CPU 860 @ 2.80Ghz to 3.46 GHz (Released 2009!!)20GB RAM (Old DDR3 1066/1333!!)1920x1080 Monitor @ 60HzMicrosoft Windows 10 Home EditionI prefer to use an old xbox 360 wireless controller, but the keyboard and mouse are also acceptable here.Graphics: I discovered that by not using the GeForce Experience "Optimize" function, and instead using the in-game autodetect feature, I get much better FPS/better looking/higher graphics settings.  VSync on/off had no real impact.Initially, I thought the environment was empty and very limited.  No other players to see or interact with.  It is a HUGE mountain range and you are free to roam anywhere.  Your only limitation when you start is you are level 1 and can't see/use everything available just yet.  I started to wonder if a refund was in order and if all the negative press about Ubisoft was true.  After roaming around and getting a feel for it, I reached level 2 and all of those feelings of dispair and uncertainty melted away as the world around me suddenly sprang to life.  The difference was like night and day and it was astonishing.  Steep was slowly preparing me for what I was about to exprience.  The scenery, physics, music, control, customization options are stunning.  I see others around me now and we join each other in this amazing winter playground.  Not a ton of people, but just enough to make the social aspect satisfying and not overbearing.I can't even begin to describe the fun I'm having playing this and I know writing too much will prevent customers from reading this.  My advice?  Buy it.  It's a nice change from all the violence and such associated with most games today and it's very relaxing.  Absolutely brilliant.

content:
Posted: January 2
												(Posted on 1/2/17) level 11 as I write this review, so review is still in progress other than Pros/Cons(1/3/17 edit): Now level 13, and would like to update my review (I will mark new pros/cons with the word "edit")This is probably one of the best snow-sport games I've played in a long time. I remember back when Shawn Whites Snowboarding came out and thinking it was absolutely amazing. Nothing really seemed to top that game for me, not even SSX, but this game definetely takes the cake. Ubisoft has done an amazing job on this game, though I wish that they had advertised it more, because it definetely deserves more attention than it is getting.Pros:-Large open world to explore-Variety of different activities to do (i.e: Snowboarding, Skiing, Wingsuit/Base Jumping, Walking)-A lot of customizability in what your character wears and the equipment he/she has-Amazing visuals (i.e: realistic looking snow, rocks, particles, etc...)-Real life products (i.e: Red Bull, GoPro, etc...) if you really care about that sort of thing-Great song playlists that vary from "Chill" to "Electro", ect...-Replay feature that allows you to go back and watch your most recent ride, even in slow motion-Not too many bugs from what I can tell-Has PS4 & Xbox controller compatability-(edit) Very well optimized for PC from my experience (cannot speak for others)-(edit) Microtransactions aren't all up in yo face constantly (meaing you can get by just fine without paying for microtransactions)Cons:-World has borders which makes it feel small at times-$60 price point, may not be all that worth it for some people + a $20 season pass with 3 DLC's already in the works-Game requires internet connection-Wonky keyboard controls-Checkpoints in races are a bit buggy at times (i.e: riding through them but it not registering that you did) which can be quite annoying-(edit) There are microtransactions (despite my pro, microtransactions are cancer in general)Current Rating:7.5/10*I will edit this review in the coming days if I feel the need to*

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												Having followed this game since I saw it unveiled on an E3 stream, I was eager to try it out. I tested it when the open beta was released on Steam and I wasn't disappointed in the slightest, the game hadn't visually changed much at all since it's unveiling, yet the actual experience of playing it myself was very different to watching someone else doing so, and I spent a good few days grinding out the available challenges alongside my friends and generally enjoying the free roam aspect of the game. Of course, as a beta it wasn't without it's strange behaviour and minor bugs but I had expected that, despite the inconvenience at times.  I had a good while to decide on whether the experience was worth spending money on for the full game and later, after christmas day, I decided I'd indulge myself and buy the game proper.Getting down to brass tacks about the finished product I can tell you that the game, once again, still hasn't made much of a change since the beta. In fact, I was kind of disappointed in how little had been done since then on account of a fresh new set of bugs and what seemed to be barely, if any tweaking to the games mechanics, thankfully the biggest change I could see was a tweaking of the G-Force system which I'll explain a little bit later on. Overall, Steep is a fun, open world experience with a charm that other snowy, mountainous sports games from memory seem to not manage to pull off in quite the same way. Initially, the game is set up to treat you like some kind of extreme sports rising superstar in generic fashion and, to be honest, I found it to be a lot more distracting from the overall experience of the game, since when you're out and about freeroaming and not partaking of the countless public challenges that dot interesting routes across the map, you can really take in the beauty of the sun shining on fresh snow, with a good ambient track to fill the silence, much like you probably would if you went skiing in the alps on holiday in real life. However, if you're not like me, the game is not without it's own soundtrack, comprised of a small selection of premade, dynamic playlists of a few genres that suit the game's setting and theme, in particular, I found it amusing to be cruising down a mountainside, weaving in and out of some blue glacier outcroppings glistening in the late afternoon sunlight to some almost zen like music only to hit a bump and smash my pretty face against one, the track throwing itself off and fading out while dusted myself off and shook myself back into reality, only to fade back in once I'd sorted myself out and got back underway, quickly dropping me back into the game before I could think of booking a much needed appointment at the nearest alpine dental practice.The free roam aspect really is the meat and potatoes of the game, it's clear to anyone that the developers spent most of their time building the game around this, as you can waste a few hours simply travelling from one range to the next, finding new routes to experiment with or simply to enjoy the view, both of which can be customised by the option of changing the position of the sun or the ambience of the weather. Riding down the same mountainside in dark fog is a very different experience to doing the same in clear, cold sunlight! This is not to say that travelling around the map is a slow and laborious process, as you're given the ability to teleport between preset locations at will with the option of discovering many more along the way and, once you've unlocked the ability to do so, you can choose to teleport via helicopter to any part of the map you choose. For those hardcore masochists, if instant and near seamless travel is not your thing, you could spent a whole heck of a lot more time trying to walk back up the mountain if you're willing. Another aspect to the game is the flighty side - wingsuiting and paragliding. Of the four sports in the game, wingsuiting appeals to me the most, it is by far the fastest and most intense way to travel in the game, requiring fast reflexes and precognition if you don't want to turn into alpine pâté. Paragliding is the opposite: a much slower, more relaxed method of travel best for taking in the views while you sail along the mountainside.For those that like to spend a little time tailoring their online image, Steep offers a few preset, voiced riders, all of which play in the same manner, but a LOT of clothing combinations for you to spend time deciding on. Some of the costumes you can get are incredibly amusing the first time you fly off a mountain or sail past someone, taunting them like a squeaky toy or a Yeti as they faceplant repeatedly.Now, this game isn't perfect. In fact, in friendly competition, I've had more than a couple of colourful words to say about some of the mechanics of this game, most namely the G-Force system, which for a game that has a fairly comprehensive tutorial at the beginning, does absolutely nothing to explain, leaving it up to mere speculation as to the finer details of how it works. This mechanic can be downright infuriating if you're a completionist like I am as it makes your job of nailing a perfect jump or getting a race time down to an extremely fine margin a living nightmare. You WILL notice what I'm talking about simply through the course of the game. Heading down a steep slope before mounting a ramp for a jump, if you so much as tap your board or skis on the tiniest bump before reaching that ramp, you can say goodbye to your legs and spine, and enjoy your new diet of your own teeth and liquid hospital food, and a lot of the challenges are purposefully set in locations that have these hazards, adding a level of difficulty that sometimes isn't even related to the challenge you're trying to do. Trust me on this one, it sounds part and parcel for a mountain game but you'll see what I mean when you have to retry the same challenge over and over and over again. It really does test your patience in certain places.Aside from this intentional yet seemingly unreasonable mechanic, the few other cons I have with this game are rather unintentional. This game is, for some reason, an online-only game, meaning you CANNOT play offline or, that if you have sub-par internet like I do, you can run into a few annoying issues such as lack of other players that are supposed to dynamically appear and disappear around you when in range. (A feature of the game, but a sort of psuedo matchmaking or instancing system), making the game rather lonely and desolate at times, with only the annoying narrator shouting generic motivation to their supposedly biggest bread winner over the radio every now and then. This is tied with the games current instability, for example, occasional but random freezing that happens in game, usually at critical moments where you're at high speed, mid air pulling off a trick, or in the middle of winning a difficult challenge. It doesn't last for long, but it seems to be reported as happening to a lot of the playerbase, as well as all the friends I know that have played it.All of that said, I don't regret buying Steep, I can sit and play it for a few minutes to pass the time or a few hours and still come away feeling like it was a worthwhile use of my spare cash. My advice to those reading this far into this review is thus: Do NOT buy this at full price. I got it on the christmas sales and it was an adequate price for what I consider to be a better than average game.I think of Steep as a relaxing, elaborate time waster, a calm immersive experience set aside from my usual library of carnage and mentally engaging games. Sure, there is an element of challenge to this game, it can be brutally unfair to you a lot of the time but if you keep your cool on those icy slopes, you'll find yourself enjoying the stunning vistas, fantastic sound effects and a surprisingly long lasting (yet not quite fully polished) ride down some impressive mountain ranges.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												So you probably were like me and keep coming back to this games store page thinking, "Man I would like a really good snowboarding/skiing/wingsuit game for PC! But this game is only "Mostly Positive"..."  Fear not child, for I have good news.  Steep is a very good game.I LOVED the SSX games.  Have probably a collective 400+hrs in that series. If you are looking for a game like SSX, you will get some of the things you want and some things you don't want out of Steep.  Before I say what these are I just want to say that I realize as I played Steep, that even though I wanted a game like SSX at first, I realized what I really just wanted was a snowboarding game that feels good in it's controls and is confident in what it's trying to be.  Steep is both of those things.You will like: + The CONTROLS feel good.  They are tight and responsive.  You feel in control of what you are trying to do.+ The GRAPHICS are very nice.  Very big and varied enviriontments lush with detail. Lighting is awesome.  Animations are great.  Snow looks better than any other game i've played. Overall awesome atmosphere.+  The SOUNDS are very good. Great soundtrack.  Nothing too specific to mention.  The sounds just do their job well.+ The REPLAYABILITY.  Some people may not be able to sit and play hours worth of this game in a single session (I can because I like exploring).  But regardless, this game has A LOT of challenges to complete.  You wont be done anytime soon.You may not like:-+ The CHARACTERS.  I feel some of the characters and their voices can be a bit dramatic and cringy.  Others are much better at not sounding so ridiculous.  However, some people may like this.  I'm indifferent about it.-+ The PHYSICS.  On the whole, I like them.  However I think that everyone who has played this game can agree that sometime your skiis or snowboard just act kinda "funny" when going over a slope or bumping into something. sometimes you remain connected on the ground when it feels like you should've left the ground for a second or two.  Sometimes you just turn to tight or lose momentum when it feels like you shouldnt have.  The thing to remember here is that these instances are rare on the whole and the positive physics experiences outweigh the bad by a considerable amount.-+ The PRICE.  A lot of people keep mentioning the price of this game being too expensive.  I do not agree.  I bought this at $60 and I definitely feel like i've gotten my moneys worth.  However, I seem to be in the minority on that one.  Keep in mind though that if you love snowboarding and skiing games, and love to explore, I dont think the price will bother you.Overall, If you are looking for a great extreme snow sports title I just dont think you can go wrong with Steep.

												I've played a lot Shaun White Snowboarding and SSX when I was younger, so I was quite hooked when Ubisoft announced Steep. After playing in the closed alpha and both betas I can safely say: Steep is an excellent sports game and the best of its genre.The controls are intuitive and the trick system is easy to learn. There's a replay feature which lets you rewatch/share your latest sessions and create challenges.The open world is huge and it looks absolutly stunning. When you're looking down from the top of a mountain for example.If you like skiing or snowboarding games, this is the game you were looking for.I'm sure this game will calm me down if the winter is like last year.EDIT: They just added a new world: Alaska. It's just as big as their previous map, the Alps. You're also able to grind rails now. And they added a bunch of new tracks to the playlists.Mura Masa <3 All of that for free!Thanks Steep Team!

content:
Posted: January 17
												Steep is a great game.At first I have to admit that I was blown away by the open-world and the mountains themselves (I worked on Mt.Blanc for many years) but quite disapointed with the maniability of the game. The controls felt clunky and it took a while to get used to the system.Having 4 sports to choose from really puts the game on another level. I really enjoyed exploring the map by paragliding around and found the windsuit exhilirating. Skiing is quite fun but snowboarding definitly takes the medal and after a few hours of gameplay it becomes pretty obvious that Steep was directly inspired but the S.K.A.T.E. Series. It is much either though and I will be hoping that Steep 2 will be a bit harder.Pros:Open WorldReal mountains4 Sports to choose fromMultiplayer unexpectedly funScoring system (freeride/freestyle/extreme)Cons:Trick system too assisted and too easyNo real career modeGear is only estheticMusic tracks will change if you reset your characterIMPROVEMENT IDEASA better trick system: The actual controls are too permissive. Since there is a lot of S.K.A.T.E. In this game, well go full distance and emphasise more on the analog sticks. Make tricks harder, add a trick list, make landing more intuitive and less assisted.Snowmobile: open flat areas would be perfect playgrounds for the snowmobile, that can have it's on trick system. In multiplayer mode you could pull other players behind you.Kickers: Build your own jump. Define the size, angle and slope. You could gain speed by being pulled by another player on a snowmobile. Kickers can be used for taking off and landing.Snowline: Area walls, really? The best wall in this game would be... no snow. The ground at the bottom of the mountains are bear of snow and grass is appearant. No frozen lakes but water. Rivers could come out of glaciers around this altitude.Punitive bails: You fall off a cliff and only K.O? Respecting the mountain means understanding how dangerous it can be. Show the broken bones of the crashed player model, make them loose a bit of money or make heir gear show damage!Snow conditions/Avalanches: Making people more responsible when they go up the mountain to ride in real life and not get carried away after playing too much Steep by adding a disclamer on the loading screen is not enough. That also has to be implemented in the gameplay. The snow conditions (it's thickness, the max speed it allows, how you can land on it) could change and dangerous areas could appear, creating the conditions for a player to create an avalanche. Other players caught in it would bail but the player that started it would have to take responsibily for other player's demise.Proximity bonus: Having your avatar score points next to a player of your group should add a bonus of share some of the points.Helicopters: Make them flyable! Instead of having am automatic sequence and tickets, why not make a great simulator where you can carry other players around? It would be an end-game unlock.You could have to pay for your fuel and be paid by other players. I know this might sound like I want an Arma version of Steep but having one player pull off a double flip above a helicopter controlled by another player is just too rad.Replay/HUD: Replay mode should be deepened. Static cameras, keyframes, more speed variations, and the possibility to save the replay as a standalone video.That's it for now! I'm going right back into it, if I have more ideas I will probably come and make an edit. Tell me what you think!

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												I am biased as this is the first game primarily made by Ubisoft Annecy, my hometown. It is not one of the best in tricks-based snowboarding, especially compared to SSX. It is more of a pure winter sports/mountaineering game. Playing steep brings back memories of my own skiing, obviously not completely true to life, but containing enough little touches you can really feel there at times. The chalets are convincing, as are the pine forests, and the crunch of the snow when you're on foot is perfect when you're stuck in a snowless piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥city and longing for the mountains of home.I realize I am getting tacky and dramatic, but Steep put me in the mood for that. See, above all, though, it is a gushing love letter to the mountains and winter sports, and it is impossible not to like it when you're a boy of these regions.Is the midnight ride with a personnification of the Pointe Percée chanting the wonders of the mountains a bit tacky ? Yes. But tacky and overly passionate is a rarity in current year's video games. It's made by mountaineers, for mountaineers, and it shows.It is not exempt of faults by a long shot. The physics are often pretty ♥♥♥♥ed, there are no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ski lifts when they should be shaping the landscape, the places named in reference to the real Alps have pretty much nothing to do with reality (though in regards of the refuge de leschaux, putting a traditional chalet was more tasteful than the real thing), the tricks system is awkward and a bit too restrictive, and the snowing effects are tame. But the game set out to make a game where you're free to ♥♥♥♥ around the mountains as you please, and by all accounts it succeeds at it. It even dares being very well optimized, with smooth 60 fps and barely any load times even when teleporting.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
 I don't recommend this game to the average gamer for 3 reasons: -$79.99 (CAD)-There is no campaign-Playing with a m + kb is atrociousThat being said,  this game is definitely better than SSX, Shaun White Snowboarding, SNOW or whatever other snowboarding or skiing games are out there; and if you are a hardcore ski or snowboarding fan, I would recommend buying this game on sale like I did. The physics are on point, and the graphics and environments are stunning. Afaik, these mountains have been mapped 1:1 and skiing them is definitely a thrill. The first comparison that comes to mind is Skate. The game feels like the winter version of Skate, and in sort of a mixture of Skate 1 and 3 in that it is realistic in some aspects but can also be more arcadey. (you can land and ski on jagged rocks to a point before you fall) I definitely think that the devs did a good job in capturing the feel of these winters sports and this is coming from someone that has skied their entire life and also dabbled in snowboarding. I think my one issue with the physics though is that skiing left and right is a bit awkward and upward cutting angles dont really work. The character loses speed way too quickly and starts reversing. Its almost like they're forcing you to go down the hill, but it does present problems in trying to navigate the vast mountains in the game.The lack of a campaign like Skate or Tony Hawk's games makes me balk at the full 79.99 price tag.  The challenges are fun, but if you are good at the game you can get through them quite quickly and they only add a couple of new ones a day. This game has incredible potential for an amazing campaign with an engaging plot, but they decided to go in the complete opposite direction and make it a sandbox. Despite the fact that game's mechanics are solid, you'll most likely end up spending quite a bit of money for the amount of time you end up playing this game.I got the season pass, so I'm looking forward to the addition of the new sports.Bottom line: If you aren't passionate about 1 or more of the sports in this game, move on. Also, gamepad is a must

content:
Posted: January 29
												Finally a new sports game that comes to PC. Steep is beautiful, it's massive, and it's straight up relaxing. A little frustrating with challenges, but enough to leave you satisfied when completing them. I prefer skiing to snowboarding, however the tight trails really make you lean more towards the snowboarding side. The views are absolutely gorgeous at times, and being able to change the time of day and ambiance really spices up the immersion. I highly recommend this game if you find relaxation in sliding down a giant snowy mountain. Don't think you're going to be pulling off SSX tricks though because that's not happening. I spent the first few hours learning how to play, the next few admiring the scenery, and the last couple trying to be competitive. Now that's the good stuff about Steep. Am I going to say there isn't stuff that bothers me? of course not. There is a bunch of things that bother me, just not enough to rant about and hate the game. Physics could be fixed, but I believe Ubisoft can fix these things soon enough as nothing is game breaking.Thanks for a solid game, Ubisoft. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												So far so good. Plays very nicely with barely any performance hiccups. Game runs flawlessly completely maxed out including 8x MSAA anti-aliasing method. Graphics look "ok" but nothing mind-blowing. Load times are insanely fast allowing you to just re-start events after falling in an instant and allowing you to teleport to the top of the mountain to try a different path all that much easier. Exploration is key and the game really doesn't hold your hand after the tutorial and let's you play it your way. Very large map, lots of customization options, a seemless online multiplayer experience and an overall great game. Highly recommend if you're a fan of snowboarding games. This is MUCH better than Shaun White Snowboarding or that trash-heap "Snow" indy game.For more in-depth review, check out my video review. It's processing atm but should be ready soon.

content:
Posted: January 22
												I'm really enjoying Steep. The controls are easy to pick up, and it's fun playing through the numerous challenges trying to better your time or score. If you visit mountain tops or some of the easier challenges, you can find other people to join and either race against or explore with. Personally, as a real-life mountain person, I love just freeriding off the beaten path until I reach the edge of the map. It's an experience you don't often find in a video game. Snowboarding and skiing are great, and wingsuiting is exciting, but a bit more difficult. Paragliding is slow and boring, though sometimes the best way to travel from peak to peak. I haven't bought the DLC yet, but would like to have the sled option, too.As for performance, I've had no problems worth mentioning. The game looks great and runs smoothly on my machine (i7-4770K, GTX770, Windows 10).If you're a sports fan or outdoor lover, then Steep is a must have. Others might enjoy the novelty for a few hours, but that's probably it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												If your a big fan of extreme sports games there's nothing like it in this era of gaming. There has not been an extreme sports game like it ever. Even though Tony Hawk Pro Skater 5 came out in 2015 it wasn't that good and the controls felt unnattural compared to the previous titles. And the game didn't even come out for PC but that's a good thing because console peasants understand what a bad port feels like. I have Tony Hawk Pro Skater HD and it's terrible everything about it. We haven't got an SSX game in a while probably 10 years. And we need to embrace that this is a game that is a spirtual successor to SSX Tricky and Tony Hawk Pro Skater. When this game first came out of course with Ubisoft the controls are not gonna be up to par and network connectivity wasn't going to be the best. That's with every Ubisoft game that comes out for open beta and even full release. Ubisoft did great with Shaun White Skateboarding. I had it for the Wii and the controls were excellent, it's replayability was awesome and it had personality.I got for PC last June and I love the game I just hated how it lacked the option to use a controller. But it was still good. I'm Glad that Ubisoft didn't ♥♥♥♥ it up compared to the studio that made the last Tony Hawk Games. This game has excellent controls,personality, it runs well and looks gorgeous. It doesn't need a beefy system to run games on high settings at 1080p. It's not boring and not anything you'll expect from a sports game nowadays and it's being constantly updated and it's way better than the open and closed beta, The unlockables make me feel like I accomplished something and I haven't had that feeling in almost a decade when it comes to video games. The only problem is the price, Don't buy the game only for $60 and the Gold Pack for $100 wait for it to go on sale for the Gold Pack, I bought the Gold Pack for $67 which is like $37 for the game and $30 for the season pass. It adds a bunch of new sports,challenges,characters and costumes for more fun and real playability with friends and strangers online. I almost picked it up on release but I was wise and picked it up while the Gold Pack was on Sale for $67. Theonline is very great and fun depending on the people your playing with of course. I've only played two hours of this game which isn't much but it's an extremely great timekiller for extreme sports finatics. The oionly thing lacking is the soundtrack and the Characters. The music is okay but it can always be better and they could've had extreme sports athletes be characters in the game for more people to be interested. But if your a big extrem sports fan and a big fan of the extreme sports gaming genre this is the best that there's to offer. SSX Tricky fans this is the closest thing to SSX in my book.

content:
Posted: January 2
												Being the skiier/snowboarder I am, I bought the game with little research. I went on to see what I liked and disliked about it, and I have to say, this is the only sports game I like. From all the other racing games/sports games, you don't have to be good or bad to play. Just get to know the game physics and tricks and you feel like a real pro! The openworld style gives you a lot of freedom, and you unlock new slopes as you go by the game, so when you're at it you don't feel like you need to go higher as you feel good at your current comfort level. The only thing that really dissapointed me was the dlc content. This game is 60.00 USD and I feel like this is a price for a full game, but the DLC offers 3 new sports for 20 more dollars. I find this greedy of Ubisoft, and should atleast have the 3 more sports in the full price. Other than that, great game, hard to find one once in a while.Pros:-Amazing Graphics-Realistic Physics-Good community-Easy to play-Many challenges and endless things to do-Many sports to choose from-In-Game currency which you don't find necessary to earn or worry about-In-Game character customizationCons:-Too high of a price-Repatitive game-Could use a singleplayer-Could use missions, ingame objectives, though there are small ones you can do

												With eleven hours in the beta, and about ten and a half more as of this review, I've really been enjoying my Steep experience.        It plays like you’d want it to. 												I can understand some mixed reviews for this game. Overall the graphics and scenery are stunning, the soundtrack/audio is excellent ( I love the crackling in the fresh powder), and about 99% of the time I enjoy the game aas a whole. I do feel there are some issues, the controls can be annoying (especially when trying to do a speedrun and you want to level your character out but then randomly flips or turns more than wanted) and the similarity of challenges can lead to boredom.  I feel those who have a skiing or snowboarding background will get the most out of this game. I love being able kick back and start a run while listening to the chill music to relax, but I do feel there can be simple additions that make this game so much better and realistic such as being able to ride snow lifts to a drop, being able to ride down to resorts or cabins as in real life and walk around, but overall this game will always be enjoyable whenever I hop on.

content:

												I bought this game during the winter sale. I saw all the negitive reviews about the price, the tricks, the glitches, everything. And I still bought it like an idiot.And I love it. I love it to death. It's a fantastic, fluid game with a good soundtrack, a hard as nails trick system that airs on the side of realism, and a fun social element to it that a lot of games just don't have.I am a huge Skate fan and I can see all of the obivious influences here, from the camera to the trick system. If you want Skate but in an SSX shell, get this. You won't be disappointed.The price is a bit sharp and the DLC's they plan on releasing is another case of "Why Didn't You Put This In Here In The First Place Ubisoft". Also if I put a full mask on a character, it clips through the face and causes a huge black dancing shadow that is super districating to show up and it's really annoying.But to be honest, I can deal with the flaws. I can deal with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game is fun, challenging, and it really makes me proud that Ubisoft, a game studio that has it's own bad track record recently, can still put out a fun and innovated and amazing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												I highly dislike this game. Which is why I love it. Steep is intense; unless you expect to spend hours repeating the same course over and over again, leave and don't come back. The first level took me around 30 minutes to master but after that most of the courses rated Easy wear easy. However, Normal and Hard is a whole different story. This is realistic. There are no save points. A tiny miscalculation can lead to a good amount of time utterly wasted on longer runs. The Normal difficulty is near impossible with anything other than the wingsuit. Just forget about Hard; it is impossible. A tap from a twig in a massive forest will require you to start over from the beginning as the AI does not make mistakes. Checkpoints, which are only on some levels, are painful to succeed in (exhibit A: just spent 2 hours on a Normal difficulty level and did not ever make passed more than half of the checkpoints; the majority of the time I only made the first two). Wingsuit is fun, after you master it and skis become decent after sometime. However, snowboarding is very non responsive in terms of tricks and the other one (parachute or something like that) is just plain boring. The visuals are immersive and vivid which is a big part of the game. It is very fun to explore and just mess around with friends but serious single player is brutal (the feeling you get when you finally win through luck makes up for the pain). Overall, I recommend the game for playing with friends but not at the full price.Enjoyment - 80/100Replayability - 100/100Community - 90/100Graphics - 100/100Developers - 90/100 (I heard Ubisoft is behaving on this one)Pricing - 50/100Finished Product - 90/100Grand Total - 86/100If this seems negative, I just spent about 2 hours on one level repeating it around 40-50 times and have not yet finished it once; I actually like the game but we have a love/hate relationship.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Although I have not played the game for too long, I believe I have played it enough to write a review about it. So for all of you that are a little bit pushed away by the game's "steep" price, this might help you out a little bit.The game is a sports game that is based around skiing, snowboarding, paragliding, and flying in a wingsuit around some big mountains (just in case you haven't figured that out yet). It is made by Ubisoft which is somewhat unfortunate due to the fact that you have to have a UPlay account for the game and Ubisoft is known for its incompetence. Despite that information it is a really solid and fun game. The controls are user-friendly which enhances the experience of dashing down a snow-covered mountain at maximum velocity. For those who have an amazing computer, you will likely find that the graphics are amazing and for those with a relatively bad computer, you will find slightly less amazing graphics, but stil amazing! Basically, the graphics are pretty sick. The gameplay is extremely awesome too (for the most part). Snowboarding and skiing are both the biggest highlights of this game compared to the other two sports to choose from. I guess the wingsuits are okay, but honestly, the paragliding is pretty boring. Despite that, the gameplay is pretty sick and definitely makes you feel like you are actually skiing or snowboarding. This game is great for both sportspeople and gamers a like, which is helpful because it allows for more players and a large variety of players. Although I haven't really done much with the social aspect of the game because none of my friends own this game, the little I have seen of it seems to be pretty solid. One thing that is really cool about the game is that it is an open world game so it feels like you have more freedom to just do what you want. You can either do the challenges or you can just mess around by snowboarding down giant hills or maybe faceplanting into a giant boulder in a wingsuit. The possibilities are almost endless.There really is not a lot to say negatively about this game. The main things that are negative about the game are the paragliding, Ubisoft, and not a lot of stat progression (which really is not a problem for me but it could be for most people). This game also has couple of bugs every now and then which comes with Ubisoft, but those could possibly be worse due to the fact that my computer is not that great.Although the game is some what pricey, it is most definitely worth it on a sale and still worth it even when it is not on a sale assuming you aren't breaking the bank by buying this game.Overview:Pros:1. Great Gameplay2. Great grapics3. Great Open-World4. Fun Challenges5. User-Friendly ControlsCons:1. Pricey2. Ubisoft -_-3. ParaglidingFinal Score | 8/10

												I invested in the game and season pass while it was on sale during winter; I payed around 60 dollars, an amount I usual refrain from spending on any game.  The reason I did this was so that I could have a relaxing game that is a break from my usual competitive, intense game. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Well.. I wish I just could write a review sooner.. But I was really busy playing the game.To me the game is made for chilling. I just go in and spend hours without noticing.Here's what my thoughts are by the means on pros and cons;Pros:1-Game is fun, whatever you do paraglide/snowboard/skii/wingsuit, doesn't matter. Game will always stun you with it's beautiful views and somehow interesting story at times.2-It doesn't force you to do missions at all, if you are bored; go around and explore, pull of stunts and share your great moments with players, dare them to a challenge!3-Map is huuuuuuge. Yeah, it's not huge. It's what you call huuuuuuge. There are places I yet to explore, but so far all I can say is that the game haven't let me down yet.4-Despite it's being only online, you can send party invites (i still haven't figured how to accept the invites though) and play with your friends, or make new friends by randomly sending invites. Don't hesitate, people always like to share good moments!5-You are not obliged to follow mission's trails (well... except it's a checkpoint one). You can always pick up new routes to achieve what the mission says, do whatever you feel like, and just have fun out there!Cons:1-Game is a bit expensive, even in winter sale, but it just gives back what it takes from you so it's not a loss at all. For me at least.2-Some stunts and tricks are really hard to pull off with keyboard, so in my opinion, it'd be better to play it with a controller.3-As I stated above, I still couldn't figure how to accept the party invites I've got. I looked up for any leads, but people claim that G key works both when you are about to send a party invite or accept it. For me, if it's working, it's 10 seconds later or around. I hoped they would make it more clear so we could actually accept the invites. So far that's all I've countered. Thanks for reading till the end.I heartily rate this game 10/10*hands a cookie*Have fun y'all!

												This game is not bad at all. The snowboarding/skiiing/wingsuiting is really fun! My personal opinion is that paragliding is incredibly boring, but once again, my personal opinion. It's fun to turn on a podcast or listen to some music and just screw around in this game. But with all good games must come some bad things. content:
Posted: January 1
												Good game but leaves much to be desired...This is another game from ubisoft that is okay but leaves much to be desired. I've had a fair bit of fun on this game doing the challenges and trying to beat my scores and just generally travelling about. I for starters wish there were more diversatiy like unless there is one and I haven't seen it yet but no ski jump I mean like proper big ski ramps or even a dedicated skiing course. I'd also love to have snowmobiles added, why is there no snowmobiles?? Would have made an excellent way to get around map and could have even more challenges like time trails and even races with them would be a great addition to the game. Would also like to be able to do more tricks only two you can do a spin and flips as well as grabbing the board but would like to be able to grind on stuff for example if ubisoft add railings for example. Something I don't like. For one the walking is so unrealistic, I don't mean the walk cycle animation but seems like the character can climb up near on virtal walls covered in snow without slipping down like what? Walking could have been a challenge in itself but nope can walk up near enough anything it seems. So wish walking was more realistic. Also wish there were cable cars too as well as snowmobiles. I also don't like that everything looks samey just want some more variety. Otherwise I enjoy playing this game a good time killer if nothing else though would recommend getting it on a sale don't feel it's worth £40.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24
												DudeZ' - I have a love-hate feeling towards Ubisoft... On one hand I personally find that they in recent times have provided one of the most diverse ranges of games: from The Crew [driving] - to Far Cry - Watch Dogs - to titles like Steep [wintersport]. And each of these... they've paved partly new parths and not gone the 'given road' like emulating "Need for Speed" or "Call of Duty" etc etc. In one word: Creativity. Perhaps because of the mix of European and Canadian lead studios. At least I see for good and for bad a distinct French' tone in both game-art and game-concept as well as in the attitude towards the customer.So: Steep? Well, lets say that my background isnt beeing a total ski-freak. But still, I've done recreational alpine skiing since I was 8-9years old, and while I studied at University I took a stint not as ski-guide but as Ski-destination guide. Which pretty much means skiing after-hours 4-7 hours day for 3-4 months :- ] Sweet.AnyWho. Steep is just about as close as I've been able to get to "the real thing" while not getting my butt' cold!The feel when you'r carving your turns and try to nail the rythm... aaaah.... its juuuuust about the point where you forget you'r gaming and find yourself back in memory, carving slops in the Alps, Scandinavia or Russia.Now, I have issues. Mainly w. Ubisoft having deplorable customer-service, especially re. The Crew [their english staff - man, talk about trying to disencourage returning customers to the brand]. However, Steep - > This one has really turned my opinion about Ubi':  No sneaky micro-transactions that mar' many other brands these days. NO - instead: "Hey Dudez: Here's a FREE Expansion just about 1/3 of the TOTAL GAME". Sure enough, the game prissy-boys cry about that's theres not this or that extra glitter on their free lollypop. But hey - that's humanity for 'ya :- ]ENJOY this one - I sure did and am still doing.If you'r into snowboarding more than traditional skiing, then you might prefer other titles. But to me, that they add snowboard, wingsuit, paragliding (sweeeeet) etc. Well, thats fine. If I dont like it, it doesnt hurt my JOY in my preferred core-part.Trick-parks' - there isnt such in particular. And there's plenty of crying about this in the comments. Well, be a little creative my teenage-teddybear-huggers ;- )  Try fx. the "Whale Bone Yard" at Alaska. There's grinding for ya' if thats what your after.... Personally I dont use 5min.s on the "challenges" in the game - I just free-ride my sweet way for an hour and am happy as a squirrel whos found a pair of king size hooters' ;- ] Btw:  I do professional sports [extreme-sports] and ironically I've not been able to ski for about 10years. The risk of ruining my knees and thus my income is too high especially since I love off-piste and especially taking 'stupid' risks. Now I can live out that part of my persoality - without the RiSk - YaY :- ]]/Dr. Mabuse, aka Angry Viking.www.worldrun.org

content:
Posted: March 26
												I see a lot of people talking about Steep in a really binary way. There are the people who think Steep is trying to be a snowboarding/skiing simulator and argue that it's a realistic game. There are also the people who argue the opposite -- that Steep is trying to be an arcadey game  like the old Tony Hawk games or SSX.To me Steep is neither of those things, Steep is a game that is meant to simulate the *feeling* of skiing and snowboarding. When I'm at the top of some random mountain crest and I pick a line, power through it, and throw in a few nice looking tricks where and when it feels right, I truely get the same feeling I get from actual snowboarding (a mix of adventure and creativity). Likewise when I'm doing some challenge or replaying a race over and over to get that perfect run -- I feel like I'm playing a video game. The beauty of Steep is its ability to toe the line between a fun game and a simulation of something I really enjoy. That is why Steep will be staying downloaded and In my library for a very long time.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Since my last review the magnet boards have been fixxed and alaska has been released, the game has also received alot of polish. The game feels almost flawless still an always online game though. For this review im purely reviewing the new content as much of the old good hasnt changed.Alaska its self is massive and really mean its massive, there alot of detail and alot of oppurtunity to find your own killer line's. You can finally turn the game to night time too and i mean real night time not just moving the sun in a circle. Grinding is now a thing, Even if it doesnt score you points.Alaska and its post updates have really made the game a solid experience for all the sport's.(I still dislike paragliding but i guess thats not everyones cup of tea) I feel like the game has progessed enough to earn a 9/10 and im happy to recommend it for its current price tag now.OLD Review=== TL;DR - STEEP        Score - 7/10---Good's---Massive and well designed game world.Beautiful effect's for weather and snow on groundSimple control'sEasy to navigate menu'sPlenty of challenges with the ability to make your own and play other player's tooEverything is purely cosmeticGreat soundtrackCurrently the community behind this game is really friendly (Always a + IMO)Ability to customise your characters clothing and equipment (Free unless you decide to waste money buying the same currency you can earn super easy in game, Hounestly unless you litterally want to buy every peice of everything in the game you wont need to buy currency)Free DLC (Alaska)  - I know it's not out yet but a whole new map and your not charging a penny? thats always good.---Bad's---Magnets on our board's/ski's (Seriously if you dont time your jump right your gonna be glued to the floor)Some challenges seem rushedParagliding is boring outside of exploringSome fast travel's leave you under the ground (This is annoying but also hilarious as when you go to move it launches you into the sky)Online Required (Sadly if your on a trip and you thought maybe your "Gaming" Laptop could play this while your on the road/rails/ in the air your going to be disapointed)---Conclusion---As much as i love and have been enjoying this game since the Alpha and would love to tell you its worth £40/$60 i cant.40$ would have been a fair price for release. Yes there's lots to do in the game but if you cant find people to eventually play this with when you have completed all the challenges then your probably gonna run dry on things to do. But that being said this is probably one of the only AAA titles iv seen this year that hasnt been released broken.In its current state without any of the season pass content and alaska i give the game a forgiving 7/10
