Posted: January 3
												I had bought this game in the winter sale, for what it's worth, it's actually not as bad as everyone says, the game features a great atmosphere and the graphics are just stunning, multiplayer is definitely a great aspect of the game and even on 300 ping, i can still play fine. I was worried the game wasn't worth £26 but so far it's been great. I have a few small thoughts though, considering that there isn't much to do gives it the negative impact that eventually you will get bored even with friends, luckily though if they add more DLC to the season pass i will buy it and i have faith this game will be updated with new content because of the price people have to pay.Overall, The game is fun. There are magnificent graphics, gameplay isn't too bad, voice acting needs some work and the idea of exploration is just incedible i really hope they do update this game with dlc, but as of now i have a few tips before your purchase...Do not play this game straight or it will get boringBuy it maybe from somewhere else cheaper (unless there is a sale)This is a multiplayer game, make sure you have semi ok internetOther than that, buy this game!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												I'll be realistic, this game is not worth the full price, so buy it only if you want it really bad. Don't get me wrong, the game itself is really nice, relaxing, multiplayer winter sports vibes and such, but tho I really enjoy playing the game, as far as mechanics go, it feels a bit clunky in a slight way regarding controls and movements within the game. The game is not 100% optimized, it works great, but no 100%, oh and it does not support SLI, maybe in the future... Oh and this game is usually enjoyable only if your playing online with some friends, otherwise... being alone sucks...Pros:- map is HUGE and REAL- you can instantly change from using skies, snowboards, wingsuits and a "parachute"-thing [another thing which I forgot :)  ]- fast travel- you can share replays and routes with your mates [really awesome]- relaxing, good winter vibes- you can do a dozen tricks, but this is no SSX- you can customize your character, buy new snowboards, full body costumes etc- graphics are ok, but could be way better [sorry Ubisoft]- generally you can have a lot of funCons:- the price- the game's overall mechanics feel a little bit weird [maybe it's just me]- does not support SLI- it can become boring, but hey... you don't shoot stuff here, you only chill and go with the snow...OVERALL = 8/10

content:
Posted: February 24
												So I've been playing this game a little while I'm out skiing in the alps this season. I can say it's a very pretty game and some challenges can be pretty challenging. The physics are just meh nothing amazing. I like the game and enjoy certain aspects but Christ all mighty whatever guy chose the music playlist for this game must have some serious depression. Seriously haven't heard a single energetic song so far. I'm skiing gnarly lines and hitting big air I want some energy In the music instead the game plays some slow sad country song or what I think was coldplays most depressing song ever. Also the music track resets every time you do so you can listen to the same song 20times in a row. At its current price it's not worth the money. The fact this game is always multiplayer is just daft aswell. Unless you play with a group of friends it's a pretty pointless endevour. You will be playing solo 95% of the time and seeing other people on the mountain is a brief encounter as you speed past each other. I'm sorta stuck 50/50 if I reccomend this game or not. I'm gunna say no with all the irritations and the price tag. That coupled with the game Snow being the rival game and is free and less irritating I'm probably gunna go with no. Maybe if this game was cheaper and made offline play available.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												I refunded this game. Let us begin why.Firstly Steep could be used to describe the pricing of this game. It's worth noting I bought the game for £26.79 during the Steam Sale, yet I still think valuewise this is a £25 base price game.You may say "How can you review the game with just 2 hours played?" Well I assume this is the reason Steam made the refund time 2 hours to give the ability for the consumer to sample it enough to see whether it is enjoyable. After two hours Steep made the refund list.Don't get me wrong, Steep is enjoyable but it isn't a game you will play for a long time and you probably won't be playing it in a years time. Why? The game is repetitive. Yes this game goes for a more realistic approach similar to Skate does for skateboarding but the difference is I can still try interesting tricks in Skate that might be impossible in real life, Steep doesn't offer that luxury. The wingsuit is fun at first but ultimately tedious. The paragliding is just the worst it's boring and sure it is nice to look at the great graphics, it eventually loses the dazzling nature.What this game is really missing is fluidity. I can switch from my wingsuit to paragliding of course, but then I must land, be on foot and then switch to my snowboard. Where is the ability to attach your snowboard midair and as soon as you land go straight into snowboarding?Microtranscations, it's Ubisoft. Should be nuff said but for the unintiated Ubisoft are massive cockwombles when it comes to microtranscations. Noted it's not so bad here but basically everything ingame can be bought for real world money. Why do you need to further monetise a game which costs full AAA price and and has a season pass? This is a greedy business practice.Character customisation, very poor. Sure the ability to tweak accessories is very cool, but can I actually customise the physical aspects of my character? No I have to choose from presets. I have no clue why this is the case.I'll probably get flack from the hardcore fans of this game but Steep isn't worth £39.99, a lot of the postive reviews have even said so. If you absolutely must have this game, pick it up next time it is on sale for £26.79. It's not a bad game by any stretch, it's very beautiful, and I am sure extreme sports fans will enjoy it, but it leaves much to be desired. It's not as good as it could have been.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												After playing the alpha and beta and each version of the game improving on the last I am not dissapointed by the full release. Steep is a euphoric game, and can be enjoyed however you want. The feel of going downhill is awesome and the feel going downhill very fast is even more awesome! Paragliding around mountains and using updrafts to reach unexplored locations is sublime and is a welcome change of pace (plus you can then wingsuit back down the mountain and do it all over again!). The trick list is a bit limited however the variety of sports avaliable makes up for it and the scenerey you ride over is always changing so you never have the same ride twice. As others have said, it feels a lot like Skate 3 so if you enjoyed that game then you know a lot of what to expect. Only issues I have with it are occasional physics engine glitches and non-game play issues such as wanting a continuous soundtrack rather than having it restart every time you restrart a challenge. But these are very minor complaints compared to the fun I have had so far!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												I'm a huge snowboard fan, and at first glance, Steep has all it takes for an excellent game.Casually exploring endless gorgeous slopes while pulling off sick stunts is sublime joy of this game.Which gets interrupted as soon as the game tries to force you into narrow-scoped parts of gameplay. Which alone are not that bad if not for:-Speed and three star courses challenge controls which are not set for precision - which leads to endless attemts to beat these courses. In fact, you cannot enjoy this game fully without a decent gamepad.-Lack of well-designed progression. Yes, you have level and earn currency for outfits. But it doesn't change what you do and how you do it. It's too sandboxy and doesn't engage for lenghts. The career should be more peculiar and directional, with championships to qualify, sponsorships to chase and things to spend dough on.-Fast-travel becomes too common. New slopes get unlocked instead of being discovered - you loose track of surroundings.-In-game store lacks of major brands.-No social activities. Yeah, you can bump into couple of people here and there but there's nothing to do together to stay in touch. Ideally, you would chat with people about cool slopes while in the chairlift - to then get there and explore.-Annoying region lock. Why should Ubisoft deprive customers of choice of language? Not to say that it came with the chinese pack when installed.-Offputting price. Regardless of your region, the game costs premium. On top of that, there's microtransactions. Oh, and remember how much you paid yesterday? IT'S ON 50% SALE A DAY LATER.-Other sports are kinda... meh.Note it's just a perfectionist criticism.I rate the game 7.7/10, and will come back over and over. Just maybe not that often.

content:
Posted: February 3
Product received for free
												Pros: +Graphics are gorgeous and you can tailer the environment in your replay to get a new look. Great for YouTubers who make boarding videos. +Huge environment to roam around and play in. Each mountian is pretty unique in the type of style you journey down it.+Variety of challenges to keep you playing. Wanted it for the snowboarding, found I spent a majority of my time in the wingsuit.+Loads of unlockable gear to make a fairly unique character.Cons: Probably my biggest con:-The difficulty on many of the "Hard" challenges are practically unreachable. You might say that's part of the challenge but this is a video game. People are going to be phenominal at some of these challenges, while others will be♥♥♥♥♥♥poor (myself included). Don't make your challenge so hard that it's practically unobtainable for the average gamer. This is why you have multiple leaderboards; To show who is better than you.-Controls are no where near as bad as people review them, however, they could use some tweaking. Navigating the map and menu's for starters are unpolished IMO.-The voiceovers and tone of some of the characters is far too intense for a winter sport game. Don't take yourself so serious Steep.-The ragdoll physics become annoying really quickly when you bail at the last checkpoint because you bounced on a small snow mound at breakneck speeds. If you're looking for EA's Skate in the snow, go play Infinite Air (Half the price, and offers plenty to warant the cost). If you want to enjoy a Winter sport game with a little more production value, you won't be disapointed with Steep.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Warning, there is a possibility you will not be able to launch the game ie crashing on startup, it has nothing to do with outdated drivers or slow hardware. I can find no information on a surefire solution and have reinstalled multiple times with every kind of usual fix methods. I am certain it has to do with Uplay not recognizing the game's activation code, and closing the game right away. Will edit review once a fix has been found. The problem is only connected to Steam, Owning the game through Uplay works fine to my knowledge.Also don't downvote because the game works fine for you, and you think the problem doesn't exist, because it very much exists and is a very serious problem.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Roughly 30 hours playtime. I've reached level cap and maxed all different riding disciplines, earning myself legendary status.And you know what? It's just the beginning. I bet I'll be spending hundreds of hours on this digital vacation this game has taken me since release.There's so much to love in this game, and I'll be completely upfront; this isn't a objective opinion at all.You like starting off on a sunny hill filled with deep powder, and leisurely ski downhill, enjoing the weather, listening to some chill music? The game lets you do that, and rewards you for it.Want to jump off the most fearsome looking mountain, skydiving past rocky outcroppings that look like hell on earth, adrenaline making your hands shaky? The game lets you do that, and rewards you for it.My only nagging points are minor. The "level cap" at 25 is... Odd. I liked doing the different disciplines so much that I capped out quickly, but kept at it anyway. Sometimes, the control system and physics engine doesn't make any sense at all, and other days it's smoother than butter on a hot pan.I'm a little worried at longevity, but Ubisoft has lately had a trend with updating their games with both free and paid content that holds a decent standard. Might return to redact this in case things change.TL;DR: If you liked SSX or any similar game/series, but felt like you never had real freedom - here it is. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: January 4
												Sonny Bono's How Not To Die Simulator 2016.But seriously, a large bulk of the challenges in this game require you to dodge and maneuver through patches of trees which require more than just quick reflexes. It borders on the need for psychic abilities.When it comes down to it though, that's just the beginning of a list of design flaws that this game has. It's amazingly polished, has a ton of content, and really looks like a $60 game on the surface, but when you start to dig in, you realize that the frustrations do not make it worth even half that amount. Some of the challenges require you to get from point A to point B with no set time limit. However, if you find yourself missing a certain line, get ready to walk (and make sure to tell your family to start dinner without you, because it's going to be a while).If you're also coming into this game looking for a fine-tuned freestyle experience, look elsewhere. Steep is very obviously aimed at people just looking for the thrill of the ride and the exploration. Tricks are very simplistic and do not have a good enough amount of variations. If you're looking for a freestyle snowboarding experience, you're much better off going with Mark McMorris Infinite Air . It's definitely much less polished than Steep and has a fraction of the content, but at the end of the day, the snowboarding just feels so much better. Put both games at the $20 price point, and I'd gladly take Infinite Air over Steep any day.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Steep is a love it or hate it type of game. Its really quite difficult to tell where you'll fall in. This game is about the experience of the mountain and the comraderie of meeting other players to tear up the mountain with.  Unlike older games in the genre like SSX, you don't have a career mode or endless challenges to complete. There are some yes, but you'll finish them quickly. Steep excels in allowing you to make your own challenges and connect with other players. If you aren't fascinated with winter sports (or similar sports) and aren't really interested in the community aspect, you'll probably finish all the challenges and get bored. The controls are also very tricky. They are intuitive once you get used to them, but having to juggle all these buttons and joysticks to pull of tricks is a bit daunting at first. Similarly the game gives you some basic tutorials, but there is way more to the mechanics than is explained there that you kind of have to learn yourself. If you're riding on just what the tutorial tells you, that's probably only 25% of your capabilities. In addition to all this the game has some flaws and bugs. The UI is obtrussive and annoying. Riding and tricking is based on physics, which sometimes can flip out and cause your rider to do weird things like fly sideways off a jump or get stuck on a shallow hill. These are minor annoyances in my opinion, but can be frustrating. Especially if you're working on a difficult challenge or other player's dare and get caught out by one. That being said Steep has many good things that outweight the bad. Switching between sports on the fly is super easy and all the sports are really cool (yes, even paragliding). The environment is vast and gorgeous and the snow deformation is just breathtaking. The ability to teleport anywhere with no loading times is also a technological marvel. There are lots of awesome locations not marked on the map and plenty of cool easter eggs to boot. Character customization is extensive and the character models are highly detailed. And finally the game doesn't take itself to seriously, with plenty of goofy diversions and silly costumes to choose from. I think Steep is a great game, but I have noticed that people who really aren't into the winter sports or the community aspect are more likely to be put off by the bugs that are present. If you like sports games and played a lot of SSX you'll probably like it. If you're on the fence, wait for some updates and season pass stuff to come out.

I liked doing the different disciplines so much that I capped out quickly, but kept at it anyway. Sometimes, the control system and physics engine doesn't make any sense at all, and other days it's smoother than butter on a hot pan.I'm a little worried at longevity, but Ubisoft has lately had a trend with updating their games with both free and paid content that holds a decent standard. Might return to redact this in case things change.TL;DR: If you liked SSX or any similar game/series, but felt like you never had real freedom - here it is. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												Steep is a difficult game to assess. Despite putting 40+ hours into the game I would say that I've enjoyed less than 4 of those hours. For me, the biggest failing of the game is that despite being open-world, most challenges lock you into a fixed route where you must pass through a bunch of checkpoints. These challenges are tedious and repetative, unless you enjoy memorizing lines and repeating/refining them.However, Steep excels when it gets out of its own way and lets you be creative about the line you take. Unfortunately, maybe 10% of the missions give you just a start and end point, and leave what is inbetween up to you. One of the best ones is a multi-minute epic ride across multiple faces and ridges, but I have yet to encounter another challenge like it.Overall I would say that Steep is far less enjoyable than Amped 2 was; which the last snowboarding game I played. Pros:It has some impressive graphics, particularly the lighting effects. The wingsuit and hang-glider are interesting additions to an extreme sports game.Some of the challenges are really fun; or very rewarding to pull off.Large area to ride through.Almost no loading time when teleporting around the mountains.Cons:Most of the challenges are boring/repetative.Controls were very sluggish/unresponsive.- Note: I was using an XBOX 360 controller, which I've used for a fair number of Steam games, but Steep seemed to ignore diagonal input entirely.Using both sticks to control turning is an interesting concept, but was not a good design decision.I was unable to use the character customization screen for more than a minute due to lag (eventually crashing the program).Edit: I forgot to mention that the soundtrack is very limited, particularly compared to the Amped franchise.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26
												Very fun game, for about two hours. At the hour and a half mark, you start to get bored of doing the same run over and over again trying to get a better score or faster time. Not to mention, you can't do everything you want to do, and when you do a very nice trick in your opinion and it only gives you like 1000 points, it is very frustrating. Also, the only fun part in the game is snowboarding, paragliding and proximity flying is PAINFUL. Tutorial is dreadful, I could honestly go out for a day on the mountain and be back at the same time I finish the damn tutorial. NOT TO MENTION IT CRASHED LIKE FOUR TIMES, AND MADE ME RESTART IT! Although, I am not going to take away from the games excellent graphics that make you feel like you're right on the mountain. If you are buying the game to play with friends, I would find a different game, because you might as well not be playing with them. Sure, you are in the same world "competing", but you barely notice them and it is impossible to follow them because of the games high pace. In my opinion, if the game just showed your friends best scores, instead of being in the same world, it would be almost the same. Personally I couldn't see myself playing more than 20ish hours, and for that reason I refunded it.GOOD:GraphicsShort-term funSnowboardingLoading timeCompetitivenessBAD:Playing with friendsLong-term funParaglidingProximity flyingFrustratingTime consumingMap is quite ugly and small, tough to navigatePainful tutorialIF YOU LIKE SKIING/SNOWBOARDING ENOUGH TO SPEND THIS MUCH MONEY ON A VIDEO GAME ABOUT IT, JUST GO TO A MOUNTAIN AND DO IT YOURSELF!By the way, I had a great time in the open beta, and had tons of fun with friends. However, just the idea of spending this much money for such short-term fun baffles me.

content:
Posted: March 26
												I've played about 10 hours of this in the first 2 days of buying it and I'm very happy with the purchase.  I bought the Gold Edition, which I recommend, because it gives you access to more terrain which you will probably want.  Although the Alps (included with base game) is an incredibly vast area that could take you months to explore.  I feel that I've barely scratched the surface of the available terrain in the Alps.  This is the most fun I've had in a winter sports game since 1080 Snowboarding for the Nintendo 64.  It really captures the feel of skiing/snowbarding in deep powder.If you're looking for a game with a highly structured campaign, keep looking. This is an open-world, sandbox with the fun you get out of it being highly dependent on your own sense of adventure.  There are plenty of well set-up races and wingsuit jumps with checkpoints and opponents to keep you busy with structured events -- but be prepared to go exploring if you want to get the most out of this game.  Multiplayer is a blast, with the ability to group with three other people and take on the mountain.  You will find plenty of random strangers, sometimes in the middle of nowhere, willing to group with you.  It really adds a nice feel seeing other people doing the same lines you are doing. At 1440p on a 144Hz monitor, this game flogs my 1070-based system.  I'm not running on ultra settings, I had to take it down to "high" and turn all AA off to get 60-80 FPS.  Then I turned resolution scaling down to 0.9 so that I could get consistent FPS above 100, which is where I like it.  It still looks AMAZING and part of what makes the adventure on the mountain(s) so fun is the beauty of it all, with dynamic day/night cycles.The #1 complaint about this game coming out of the Steam reviews is the price. I got the Gold Edition on Steam Sale for $40 (50% off regular price) and I think that's more or less fair for a game that's only been out for four months.  I would not pay $80 for the Gold Edition.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Steep™  is an open-world extreme sports game that can cover your EA Skate 3 itch that you have been holding for years! You can do up 4 different sports in this game that fits your style of gameplay. There is Snowboarding, Skiing, Wingsuits, and even paragliding. It holds many challenges to do for each sport and you can even make your own for your friends to beat.If you are not big on the challenge thing, there is much exploration you can do. The map is very big and cut into sections of a couple different mountains. You can just ride or fly your way down with a breathtaking view of the whole mountain. There are areas called "Points of Interest" throughout each mountain that you can find while exploring the vast areas of the map. The physics in this game, in my opinion, might need some touch up on but it's not too bad honestly. there are sometimes where you'll just randomly get pulled to the ground when going over a hump of snow. Other times it's just completely fine. There is a G-Force feature put into the game so if you hit the ground too hard or hit too many things at a time you will crash which helps with the realism of the game and can prevent big trick spams.Lastly, there is character customization, it's not a lot but it's enough to show your personality of what you would want. There are premade characters of professional athletes you may or may not know, but you can buy different boards, skis, wingsuits, parachutes, clothes, etc. for your characters of choice.I might have only 20hrs of gameplay when I made this review, but I can see myself playing it for much more in the future since not many good extreme sports game are made often.Overall I give Steep™ a solid 9.5/10All it needs is a couple bug fixes and maybe some more songs for the gameplay if you're into music like I am.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I'll start this review by saying that the game is rather over-priced, it doesn't really have much of a purpose to it other than complete some challenges, it feels like doing the sub-quests in an Assassins Creed game. Aside from that, the game plays rather well, smooth fps and great graphics, a few minor details that could look more realistic, but for what it is right now it's very nice. The gameplay is very fun if you're interested in those addrenaline filled sports but don't have the money or the balls to actually go out and do it yourself in the real world. This game would be excellent if it was played in VR (virtual reality).One personal issue I've ran into is the game crashed numerous times, however I found out that was due to my Graphics Card overheating and going into "Nope-Mode" to save itself from any cheeky damages. I have never ran into such an issue with the card on any other games, most of which are newly realeased / high-end games. Keep an eye on your hardware temps with this one, just in case. To remedy this I moved one of my many case fans to get better air-flow to the GPU, you can also try leaving your case door off / open. This may also have been due to hot weather however it still didn't happen with other games that day. Just a heads up for anyone else on a possible issue!Anyway, I would give this game a solid 7 / 10 - loses points for being a bit over-priced and having that ♥♥♥♥ing stupid GoPro Karma drone in it, ♥♥♥♥ing worst drone ever released.. And loses points for some bad hardware compatibility. Gains points for a decently well made game despite the GPU temperature thing, sound effects are fine, graphics look great, and the gameplay has a nice feel to it.

content:
Posted: January 20
												Snowboarding is not fun in this game. The gameplay for snowboarding gives a very unpleasant sensation from the combination of bad controls, the inability to turn back up the mountain, and the awful camera. The mountain is attractive but you quickly realize there's nothing genuinely interesting anywhere. It's basically just a procedurally generated map. Ubisoft doesn't understand that the size of worlds doesn't matter if there's nothing interesting or neat within them. SSX understood this. Also you still have to use Uplay, which is pretty awful and pointless. I will give Ubisoft credit for the snappy instant transports. It's nice to be able to play nonstop without being concerned about loading times. That's a very nice part of the game. In the end, I returned this within 2 hours and daydreamed about SSX on PC.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												First off. Steep is not worth £40. i bought it when it was £26 and it still isnt worth it. the gameplay is ok but it comes with its issues. Parachuting is clunkly and awful. Skiing is fun and fast paced but after landing you seem to loose incredible amounts of speed, same with snowboarding but not as bad. The wing-suit seems to be well rounded and quite fun.Overall i would say this game is fun, but should not be priced £40, or even £26 (christmas sale). if it was £20 i would have reccomended this game but sadly its over priced.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Personally I like it but getting this at the whole price really depends on your preferences. The game is fun, you can do races with your friends on the tallest mountains and you can customize your character with points you recieve by winning different races. However, as I said, the price is a little bit exaggerated but the game has no big issues. Also, the controls are alright, and I want to mention this because I saw a lot of people being mad of that reason. It might be kinda difficult at the beggining but after 2 hours it will be just fine.If you like the winter sports and you have enough money, then you can buy it . If you like the winter sports but you can't afford spending money play SNOW instead.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												This game is a lot of fun to start off. The game is fantastic for skiing, snowboarding, and squirel suit flying. Something that people may not enjoy as much in this game is paragliding. At first when playing the game i didnt really enjoy that aspect either but the more I paraglided the more I enjoyed it because they have some chalenging fun chalenges for paragliding. Overall is the game worth $60? If buying this game for that amount of money don't do it go on sale but if its within your disposable income I would reccomend it if you in any way like snowboarding games because steep takes those genres to the next level. Also the sound track for the game in really good. You can easily space out and relax for hours at a time just messing around in this game.

												people who say this game is overpriced clearly dont appreciate good games anymore, or their just broke.this game is amazing, its complete unique style of what almost seems to be an MMO action sports game is awesome, theres always a bunch of people around doing events or just exploring the wild. TL;DR: BUY THIS GAME

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												My experience with this game can be summed as thus: every update I found myself testing the changes, nodding in satisfaction, then quitting the game to await the next update.Arkane knows how to make a good game. No question. But if you film an Oscar-worthy movie and the lens is smudged while filming, you can't judge what's underneath without acknowledging what's been marring your experience the entire time.=============================PERFORMANCE Everyone is aware of the performance issues, and these still persist to this day. It runs much better than at launch, where it was literally unplayable, but that's because the game looks worse than before - the most noticeable change being the extremely aggressive LOD scaling. Out of the corner of your eye you notice the shapes of window frames and posters on distant buildings morphing in shape, or the furniture at the opposite end of a long hallway suddenly blinking into existence. FPS dropped to 15 when stabbing a gravehound, so they simply removed the inky visual effect that was causing the problem instead of optimizing it.Also, Denuvo authentication is one of the longest "loading screens" of the game. Around half a minute to a full minute or more every startup.=============================GAMEPLAY For the most part, gameplay is excellent and is Dishonored's strongest suit. Dark Vision was changed to a blurry short range sonar so unlike Dishonored 1 you aren't constantly seeing blue and yellow because you had no reason not toAI is much smarterNonlethal combat options are a blastBonecharm crafting system allows for player flexibility and "builds"Each level feels lived-in while maintaining the duality of directive flow and open options that made the first game so good.Emily and Corvo have distinct animations and final weapon upgrades. The animations are supremely cool.Each level is fairly distinct, some with extremely interesting central "gimmicks." I do, however, wish the game relied less on them and had more "regular" areas.However, under the hood lie other problems. Most of them are quality-of-life issues:Gone are the hotkeys for journal, inventory, bonecharms, powers. Only one "journal" exists now, despite still having separate subsections.It took months for the power wheel to be fixed. It took almost a full second after activating to pop up and be usable, breaking flow so badly I almost never used it in the first place. It's finally fixed now, but this issue was glaring and it took so long to be addressed most of us played through without it fixed.Thrown objects don't always go exactly where your crosshair is. While this adds a layer of difficulty, it feels noticeably more clunky than in the first game.Mana regen is pitifully slow. From using a power to fully regenerating, Dishonored 1's time is 4.7 seconds -> 3.1 seconds with Spiritual Pool. Dishonored 2's time with 4x Spiritual Pool is 6.3s -> 5.5s. The devs said they fixed this effect, but it was only made worse.Bugs. Street speakers not playing. Dying after possessing gravehounds. An arc pylon never shutting down after pulling out its power, leaving it to either be dangerous to you to dangerous to your nonlethal playthrough. Some of these still aren't fixed.=============================STORY AND ATMOSPHERE Reactivity Great. My favorite part of Dishonored. You need to hide from a gang member to access a certain black market shop, and there are different scenarios and dialogue for if you hide, if you run into him outside, kill him outside, or kill him inside.Emily and Corvo Emily and Corvo are voiced. And... they don't talk enough. It's good that they're silent for most of the game, but there are times when you come across a portrait or photograph with an "Inspect" prompt. I'd love to hear Emily's thoughts on the High Overseer as see how that compares to Corvo's, or if it changes based on whether or not you accept the Outsider's Mark. Instead, all I get is the protagonist muttering the name of the person pictured. What's the point? Might as well keep them silent.It made sense to me to play Emily first, but her story felt lackluster, like people at every turn were saying "check your royal privilege" despite my efforts to resolve everyone's problems without drawing blood. Corvo's is MUCH more interesting as a veteran of Dishonored 1.The Outsider and The Void I hate the new Outsider and his new voice. He felt threatening and malicious in the first game due to how calm and composed he was, and the Void felt like a strange and otherworldly place. The vignettes of Dunwall made it feel both unnatural and unnerving yet fundamentally woven into the universe. In Dishonored 2, it's just smoky blackness and sharp rocks. The Outsider is much jollier and moves around erratically, making grandiose hand gestures. They actually had a plot plot that could explain this change, but it was never addressed, so it just seems like a pointless retcon to me.Main Plot Dishonored's worldbuilding was always one of its appeals, and that remains true in Dishonored 2. However, the villains felt lackluster. Only the main villain has a real presence throughout the game, whereas everyone else feels introduced abruptly only to fall by your hand, all within the same mission. In Dishonored 1 everything felt personal and real. Perhaps it was because of the long intro where you interacted with most of them, or the Hound Pits's cast of characters all having different connections to your targets.=============================As you can see, I've played this game a LOT and have put a lot of thought into it. It was definitely worth all those hours and all that money, but the condition it was at launch and the sluggish drip-feed of support we barely get now is unacceptable. To set a precedent for future games, I can't recommend buying this unless they manage to fix all the performance issues and bugs, which doesn't seem to be happening anytime soon.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												In 2004 SSX3 on PS2 was the go2 snowboarding game. 2017 This will be it! It's ok to use mouse and keyboard in this game, but I prefer to use a controller. I'm currently using a XBONE S Controller and it has some few buggs where some of the keys wont respond correctly. The toturials are one of the best when it comes to learn the game mechanics. The screen gets divided into two, where you can see the tricks at the left side, and what keys to press on a controllet at the right side. They will most likely patch some of the few response issues since this is more of a consoll game. If you like snow and wintersport this is a must buy! Also the graphic settings is a dream. You will see small windows that highlight what the different settings will show in-game. Also there's no need to restart the game for changing settings. Very good game from Ubisoft! I give it an easy 9.5/10 because a few controller buggs, othwerise an excellent game!EDIT: Few spelling mistakes

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2
												Steep is a superhero game where you are a youtube content creator in a post-apocolyptic arctic wasteland. In this world, you have an adamantium skeleton adapted to withstand an infinite amount of force. You are able to withstand a force that would otherwise kill a normal human being, and shake it off as if you tripped and caught yourself. However, this power comes at a great cost. Your adamantium skeleton is not equipped with the independent capability of jumping without augmentations such as 2 or 1 flat feet, or augmented wings. The problem still persists in your web-suit form. The world has changed very much since the present day. Every single non-youtube creator has uploaded their consciousness to the cloud. As a result, you have to have a constant internet connection to continously upload your extreme videos of you reverse-trustfalling the ground in a wingsuit or you will automatically DC and die. Also, entire villages were abandoned and no human lives in the "real world" anymore, only the corporate sponsors. This gets so riled up, like I just drank a Red Bull® and am consumed with the primal energy to strap on my GoPro® and go shred some snow in my North Face®Due to the high demand of computing power thanks to uploading of the entire human conciousness, you must acquire the best computer parts. I have made the mistake of playing this game without upgrading my 16 GB of RAM to 32 GB or closing google chrome; I lost the game after 5 minutes and the game quit automatically to save me the embarrasment. But shredding the mountain man. It's hella on fleek af fam or whatever kids are saying these days. So shred and whatnot. TL;DR unoptimized, sponsored, lack of basic controls, but actually a fun game. Wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I haven't found a game in a long time that I've cracked out on.  I used to game hard in high school, went through College, and have since moved to Colorado to enjoy all the glorious snowboarding the Rockies has to offer.  This is a sick addition to fill my free time during the work week when I can't get out to the mountains to shred.  The physics are incredible.  The touch and feel of the game really feels like you're actually on a snowboard (I can't say for ski's - I've never been).  It's a huge refresher in comparison to all the winter sports games of the past where everything feels arcade-like or ultra user friendly.  This one takes a little time to pick up.  I'll also say it gives you that same feeling of exploration that an MMO or RPG gives.  It's vast and you enjoyably get lost in the depth of it all like playing Skyrim or Final Fantasy.  All in all, a great game and should give enjoyment for months or even years to come!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Steep. The game to fill the hole in my heart that skate has left me since I switched to PC gaming so many years ago.This game is not something most people will want to play each and every day like they would play dota2 or counter strike. It's not a game about completing all the challenges or getting the level cap as fast as possible. it's a game about snowboarding, skiing, paragliding and flying with your wingsuit. Your playground is a huge place with various mountains. the game leaves you on your own and you can do whatever the hell you want.The challenges are all awesome and it feels to me that every single race is polished and balanced. I can't comprehend how much work it must have taken to build a world like this and make it feel consistently awesome.Anyway, it's not ultra-super-amazing realistic. It certainly looks like it would be, but there's some arcade mechanics worked into how the game plays, and in my opinion that's exactly how it should be! It's still a game people, if you had a ultra-realistic snowboarding game you would fall every 7 seconds.To conclude my review, I don't think I'll ever get enough of Steep. It fills my times of boredom and gives me an opportunity to just hang back and chill out. I recommend it!

												  Steep was a great game! I would have paid full price for this one. I have played each sport in the game with no disappointments. I absolutly love how the game immerses you into the intensity of the situations you put yourself in. This is a can be either a very compettetive game to you and your friends or a very relaxed game for yourself. This game is whatever you want it to be honestly. If you like time trials and compettition BOOM it's there. If you're just trying to play a game and chill, listen to music, BOOM you can take a chopper to the top of a mountain and ski/snowboard/paraglide/wingsuit down for about an hour and also explore new obstacles yourself. I am still playing the game and trying to get gold in each event but after that I'll be making my own trails to replay myself later.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												While the game is stunning in visuals and sound design, it lacks in content, consistency, and overall enjoyment.Exploration: For a game that encourages the player to explore, the exploration and freeroaming is extremely tedious. The fastest mode of transportation is you wingsuit, but there are only so many places you can launch from. However, your faster ways to move can only move you downwards. To climb a slope, you have to use the paraglider or just walk. The paraglider still confuses me because it seems you have to find updrafts in specific places to boost you upwards, and there is no way to find these other than just mindlessly floating around until you run in to one. The walking is the most controllable of the five sports, but is insanely slow. Like, I know, running in snow is tiring and hard to do, but when the only way to ge to where I want to be is walking, I'd rather not be moving at two miles per hour. Rocks:The rocky bits of the mountains are extremely annoying. While on the snowboard, even standing still on a bit of rocks will make you fall over. This places you in an endless cycle of falling over until you hold tab to try again. This means, even if you've been exploring for thirty minutes straight on your board, the game will plop you right back to the last time you switched sports. You also cannot transition from snow to rock while walking, and vice versa. This means if you flop and land on a patch of rocks, you cant just walk over and climb off, you have to slide off on you snowboard and fall over just to get off of a pebble you got stuck on. Oh, and you want to try again after that whole situation? Nope, the game will send you right back onto that rock, because you switched sports, remember?Menus:The menus could do with some redesigning. The mountain view is difficult to navigate with all the places the cursor locks on to, and the view angle changes every time you open the menu, so it is very disorienting. It took me about twenty minutes to figure out how to view my replay for a manditory mission. I was also about three hours into the game before i realised that you could actually customize your rider.Missions:There are some interesting missions called "Mountain Stories" that I actually enjoyed, because  they have a quick little story and a unique prize at the end. There was one mountain story where you had to ride around and smash these little snowmen who would taunt you the whole way through, and at the end, you recieved a neat little evil snowman mask. Also, I should mention, there are four different "classes" of rider you can become. Pro Rider, Freestyler, Bone Breaker, and Explorer. You must complete missions specific to that class to level it up. My favorite type of mission by far are the Bone Breaker missions. They are very unique and interesting while remaining fun and difficult. The wingsuit Bone Breaker missions mostly consist of flying through small caves and tunnels with multiple twists and turns. These missions are very difficult, but you dont get frustrated because any time you fail, you know it is of your own fault. The game isn't screwing you over in any way, you don't succeed due to you own capabilities. Pro Rider and Freestyler missions, on the other hand, are difficult because of your lack of control. If you are riding down a steep slope and hit a tiny bump, you go flying off into the air, and will most likely miss the next checkpoint, forcing you to restart the entire mission. The actual ramps in the game entirely destroy any momentum you had before you hit the ramp. They function more as speed bumps than anything else. Most of the time to complete these missions, you have to resort to getting off of your snowboard and walking through the checkpoints yourself.Checkpoints/"Level" Design:As I explained previously, the tiniest bumps in the earth will rocket you off into space. So, in a mission that requires speed and pinpoint accuracy, why are they all so bumpy? When the mission requires maximum control over your rider, the bumps make your rider do little jump after little jump, removing your ability to turn, making you miss the checkpoint, and restart the mission entirely. May I also add that these mission are extremely long and tedious, and one little slip will send you flying down the slope past all of your objective while you do your best to slow down. (Also, if you manage to fall over on any kind of slope, the ragdoll will fall all the way until it runs into a flat surface, and once it's there, it may continue to roll along being propelled by some unknown force, completely ignoring friction.) Okay, back to the checkpoints. Your next checkpoint is only revealed to you once you pass through the point before it, and when you're rocketing down a mountain at insane speeds, you hardly have time to react before you blow past it. Checkpoints are little spheres that you have to pass through the center of (no, you can't just touch it, you have to be entirely engulfed and then some) for it to count. This means it is very easy to zoom past over, or even through it without the game counting the checkpoint. There is, however a beacon that appears above the sphere to give a very vague idea as to where the point is. But wait! sometimes you find yourself in a little ravine where you can't see the beacon at all! You make a wrong turn to where you assume the next point will be, and whoops! You have to do the whole thing over again. A fix for this would be a minimap. Just a small little minimap that points you to the next checkpoint along with the beacon and sphere.Leveling/Content:I have played about twelve hours of this game as of now, and I am level 22 out of 25. I have discovered all the lines that I could want to ride, and played all the challenges that didn't frustrate me to the point of quitting. Twelve. Hours. It may seem like a long time in text, but to me, playing the game, felt like about thirty minutes of casual playing. You may argue that, "there's so much left to explore at the base of the mountains!" but where's the fun in that? It's not like it's gonna be some intense underground tunnel that leads to a huge slope with heaps of huge jumps and ramps. It's going to be a nice little group of cottages where you stop for a second and say, "Neato," before sliding off down the slight decline that the base of the mountains is.Okay. Now, I know I just ranted on and on about what I don't like about the game, but overall I still had a good time. The game was beautiful with great sound design and song choice, and just boarding down a slope with no objective is calming and can even be rewarding. But, for the amount of unfair difficulty and bugginess and frustration this game has given me, it simply is not worth the cost of a full price game. It provides short lived wonder and beauty followed by grinding and inconsistency and frustration. I can not say that I recommend purchasing this game.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Plenty of good stuff here.  BUT It gets old quickly and feels like a purely "sandbox" gameVery similiar to Planet Coaster in the sense that the base game design is brilliant but the FEATURES and gameplay are somewhat shallow, while still fairly enjoyable.   Any comparison to SSX or Amped is fair, but those games were really structured around racing and arcade style gameplay.Steep is like dirt in that its a semi simulation, however its lacking a sense of commitment to racing or tricks.Steep would definitely benefit from being a lot more realistic, and geared towards being a simulator that makes it more challenging.  ATM you can ski backwards over cliffs without much challenge in staying up. ITs like you just watch your rider do his thing and you dont feel really connected physically with the game because of the lack of feel.SSX is VERY dated BTw that style of gameplay would not hold up today and I think Steep has really hit the nail on what a next gen snowboard game should be. A free Open world to traverse as you please with the ability to hook up with friendsThe graphics are really good and optimized, however the gameplay and game design suffers.Im going to recommend the game purely on whats here to enjoy, but I wish it was better in so many ways8/10

												The game would not start for me.  I could see it pop up in my task manager, stay for about a minute, and then nothing.  I contacted ubisoft support and did a fresh install of my graphics card drivers which did not fix the problem, but their next suggestion was to check every single program that runs at start on my computer.  Sorry, but no.  I don't run anything unusual on my computer that would interfere with this game launching.  I checked my programs against Steam's list of frequent offenders for trouble with launching games and did not have anything on the list.  A game from an AAA game developer should run properly "out of the box", so to speak.  I also strongly resent being forced to download Uplay.  I've already requested a refund.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												The game looks and sounds great, but the controls and gameplay just don't feel right.I played through the tutorial and it was looking promising. I liked that I could change between the different travel modes at any time, anywhere. Puzzling though, was the paragliding races...really pointless and boring.The main gripe I have with this game is how much momentum I lost from making jumps with my snowboard. On one course, I was speeding down the mountain and saw a sloped roof that I thought would make a nice launch pad for some tricks. Now you can't just speed up onto the roof and jump off. Instead, you'll hit the bottom of the sloped roof and fall down. So I figured I must be able to do a little hop onto the roof and then zip up and do my incredible jump! But no. Whenever I tried to jump onto a slope and use it to launch from, my speed dropped dramatically and well...failure.So where my journey really ended was right after the tutorial. I encountered a snowboard half-pipe. I don't know what I expected, but as I tried to get through, I just ended fizzling out at the bottom with no speed.I get it it...it's supposed to be realistic. No super jumps that can keep on giving. I guess I just wasn't prepared for how realistic this game wanted to present itself. It just isn't fun at all.I just have different expecations after growing up playing the SSX series. Pity that never came to PC!Summary: Controls are not great and the game tries to be too realistic for its own good.

content:
Posted: January 26
												Well, what can I say, as a person who skis from time to time I was excited. Excited to see a game that would let me do the stuff I would never really do on the hill. Excited for the promised massive open world and "infinite Possibilities". Well that's not what this is, and its definitly not worth the  80$ price tag  . Not even on sale would I recomend this game to anyone. Firstly the controls, by god, they are bad. You spend most of your time skiing backwards when you want to ski forewards. Grabbing in the air while doing the same spin for the 50th time and trying to get up while clipping into a building, The wing suit is cool, and if the dev team made the other sports as refined as it, maybe this would be a good game. But the final nail in the coffin known as steep comes in the fact that there is  no offline mode . No Wifi? oh sorry guess you can't be a part of a game that gears itself to online play where you don't actually interact with other people.

content:
Posted: March 26
 Best Steep Review [/h]Hello,Steep is a good game. However, repeditive. The game has a steep price tag, and you should buy it when on sale, not for $60. It's better that way.Steep is a repetitive game, just like this review. After playing for a while you'll be like "Wowzers I've been going down the same 3 mountains for 5 hours now, in two different ways" You only use 2 out of the 4 sports in the game.  (Let's be real here, no one enjoys paragliding and ski's are for noobs)  The game randomly crashes sometimes when loading. SPEAKING OF WHICH~ there is no loading times. Once you are in the game teleporting to places is instant, there is no load screen at all in this game. Game includes autosave. I'd recomend a controller, I personally use my PS4 controller. The keyboard controls are a little bit awkward, but are still enjoyable :DGraphics are good, the game actually allows you to run your own benchmark in the game, to see which graphics would be the best for your system while keeping a playable framerate. It also shows you, when changing them, what the graphics will look like in game. Multiplayer is okay. Playing with friends is more like "Aye my friend is in the game that's cool" then one of you leaves the other in their dust. Mission are fun, however  THE TAILING MISSIONS ARE LITERAL TRASH AND SHOULD BE REMOVE  That's all.There isn't too much of a story,  you're an upcoming pro rider. You have different "shoots" to promote your character and unlock new missions. Long tutorial but covers all grounds.

content:
Posted: January 17
												I like it a lot, but I'm also a sucker for snowsports games. Reaching the level cap of 25 can be done pretty quickly, but actually doing every challenge (especially up to gold medal standards) will take a while unless you've entirely mastered the physics system and memorized every mountain face.Pros:-Huge amount of mountain terrain to explore with lots of unmarked stuff to find-Visually beautiful-Skiing and snowboarding have subtle differences that make each of them worth trying-Soundtrack is well-designed for snowsports with a good variety-Challenges are usually easy enough to get in one try-Replay editing makes you feel like an amateur Warren MillerCons:-Always online means you better be sure your connection is steady at all times-Multiplayer feels a bit tacked on, haven't really seen any sort of reason to play with others unless you really need a score multiplier boost-Physics are occasionally inconsistent, but no more so than Skate or any other extreme sports game-Not enough music in the soundtrack, you will hear repeats very often when you're restarting a challenge-Controls take a bit to get used to, mostly due to automapping the jump/ollie function to controller triggers-No grindable surfaces, which feels a bit glaring considering almost every extreme sports game has had this-Season Pass is not worth the price, and it's arguable that the base game price is a bit steep *badump tish*If you're looking for a game where you make your own fun setting up lines and editing your footage, then Steep is certainly going to give you a lot of playtime and material to work with. If you're looking for a next-generation SSX game, then you'd better keep looking.

number of helpful: 15 of 33 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												As an avid snowsports enthusiast I honestley wanted to like this game. You can choose to belive me, or write me off as some kid who has never been in snow a day in his life. I've been skiing for 9 years, and started snowboarding 2 years ago. I spend every weekend at our local resorts, and go after work during the week sometimes. Thats where I noticed the first issue on this game. The controls are very rigid feeling, movements simply don't transfer as expected and you notice the little bugs fairly  quickly. Theres no chance to catch your edges on either skiis or the snowboard and all you can do are basic grabs, spins and flips, which the mechanics for are absurd. There is almost no variation for park terrain and there are no boxes / rails present anywhere in the game. Gliding through pine trees poses no tree well risk, theres not really any hidden rocks or drops either. I wanted to love this game, but after 2 hours it just feels so stale already. The challenges are all "go here and ride this" "go here and do 12 seperate backflips" It's just not worth $60. Tl:dr I've been on mountains for years, the realisim in this game is completley missing, the missions get incredibly stale and it's just not worth $60 for a "full game". If there was more terrain, and a grinding system, more control over your ride ect. I would come back. But for now, it's time for the steam refund process.

content:
Posted: January 1
												To get straight to the point, this game is not worth the $40 on sale, much less the $60 it costs when not unless you absolutely know that this is the type of game you could never get bored of.Now, about 20 minutes of my almost two hour playtime was trying to get it to actually work, because I had to uninstall the game three times before it would stop crashing on start-up, so there's that. Once I got into the game is what pretty fun for a while, but I stopped in fear that I would exceed the two hour limit mark of essentially, "free" play time because I wasn't sure if I actually would play this game enough to put the $40 I spent to justice.Eventually the next day I came back and played for about 60 minutes, but thankfully stopped just in time before the 2 hour mark at 117 minutes. The thing is, the game is so linear that it's basically just five ways to go down the mountain till you get close enough to drop points and challenges to spawn at so you can then do those challenges to increase your rep to unlock spawn points higher up on the mountain so you can repeat the entire process.So like, here's a really bad analogy of the progression of Steep.Say Steep is like a layered fruitcake.The top of the cake is the top of the mountain, the bottom of the cake is the (you guessed it) bottom of the mountain.You start at the relatively bottom of the mountain with fruit surrounding you. The fruit represents challenges.Now, you start off doing the challenges around you, which gains you reputation.When you recieve enough reputation from challenges, you get to progress to the N E X T L A Y E R O F F R U I T C A K E .You start at the top of that new layer, and are tasked with making your way down the layer in any means you're given.Thus, the process repeats itself till you're at the top of the mountain.Pretty linear, if you ask me, since the challenges are basically split into two categories among all of the four sports.Skiiing and snowboarding which are on the ground has challenges split into two groups and they are either:-Ski/snowboard down the mountain as fast as you can.or-Ski/snowboard down the mountain at your own pace but you have to do tricks to get points.Wingsuiting and Paragliding are the other two sports which are a bit different.Wingsuiting challenges are either:-Wingsuit down the mountain as fast as you can, while going through the checkpoints.or-Wingsuit down the mountain while staying as close to the ground or other objects as possible.Paragliding goes like this:-Paraglide as fast as you can through some checkpoints.or-Paraglide at your own pace while doing some flips and♥♥♥♥♥♥Now these are pretty linear, making the game seem pretty repetitive after a while so unless you REALLY like the concept, you'll be wasting $40.

												Steep is a really fun game! number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												oh my god where to start, half of the methods to play are absolute joke the wingsuit controls like a robot and isn't fun to use. the parachute is slow and boring and also not fun to use. Skiing and snowboarding are the only worth wild mode to play the game in and they're basically carbon copies of each other, the soundtrack consists of four songs of which I had heard all of by the end of the tutorial. The speed at which you move is unconstant it'll seem to drop rapidly for no reason and takes any fun out of your ride, multiplayer offers no fun and the terrain of every map is uninteresting or at least I think it is since I was blocked off from a large section of the map. this would be fine if the map that I had access to was interesting whatsoever but its not. Tricks are a b**** to pull off and the game seems to throw arbitrary Point numbers your way that seemed to correspond very little to what you're doing you could have crashed your keys and I'll just pop up a number like 1204 and then do a triple backflip and get a number like 359, this makes actually pulling off tricks unrewarding and unnecessary. Some environmental objects that seem like they would be excellent to do jumps off of we'll just stop you in your tracks for no reason, not even crash you just flat-out stop you. for this variety of reasons I'll be returning the game and I won't be purchasing it again unless ubiesoft make some large changes to both the price tag and the game even if the sale price of $40 this was overpriced I wouldn't pay 15 for it in its current state, On the upside the game looks beautiful and runs pretty smoothly on my PC, but Graphics do not make a good game, the four songs that felt like they repeated weren't terrible as soundtracks go and the ambient sounds that weren't actual songs were pretty smooth, the idea behind the multiplayer isn't fundamentally flawed it's just not executed well interaction is minimal and since any race tracks are custom made by players using the lacklustre environment, racing isn't fun not because the multiplayer is bad but because Raceing isn't Fun in single player either the same goes for the other styles such as the Free Runs are the trick battles or whatever, maybe this game is just not for me but I can leave you a list if you were a big SSX fan or anything I don't think this game is for you, it won't offer that kind of high octane s*** or interesting environments, it actually makes me want to go back and play the most recent SSX which was a subpar game its self, but I would easily find myself enjoying it much more than steep. i have returned the game after just under 1 hour of play time and i got all this from that, if you think it get better latter go for it but i dont see it happening.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												The game is great but with flaws, the powder ain't as clean as they dream so to speak.Open world snow boarding ah simple idea that can have a lot of fun but the issues here are many,to start the world is fairly small, the edge of the map comes quick and going for a realistic mountain but smaller is not the best idea because you get to see snow, trees, snow, ice, snow...Ok so how about tricks, challanges and collectables, the bread and butter of an open world sports game?There are no collectables, you can not grind down a skii lift grabbing things along the way, there are no ice caves as you hop using ramps from place to another grabbing stuff mid air, there are no strings of things to pick up as you narrowly dodge trees in an alpine forest. You have a mountain and a snowboard/skis so have fun...haha no.The challanges are very basic but often hard because of the broken physics (more of that in a min)and the tricks are just...hmmm right.Let me tell you about the tricks, you know how in saw tony hawk skating games to do a mid air trick you get in the air and then press a button or rotate the stick? Well in steep ramps give tiny amounts of air and you have to imput the tricks ON THE RAMP, meaning to do a left rotation you have to hold R2, go on the ramp, let go of R2 as you move the stick but only mid way on the ramp, too early or too late and the game WILL NOT LET YOU ROTATE OR EVEN TRY.Oh my god is the trick system annoying and there is barely any, you can rotate and do barrol rolls, board grabs and that is pretty much it!Ok so you have a fairly small map with no collectables, nothing interesting to see or explore with a wonky trick system, what is next? Ah the broken physics i mentioned before.You have a HP bar known as a "g-force bar" where if you hit the ground with too much speed or run over rocks you lose a bit but i have lost half my bar just..moving down hill in a straight line, landing a trick (i remind you the ramps give tiny amount of air) can drain almost all of it sometimes and when you are in a high speed race that demands perfection even on medium differculty it adds up to pure rage.TL;DR-Small map-Broken physics-World has nothing to see or really do-Trick system is annoying and unsatasying-£55/$70 gold price tag, disgusting+fairly fun for at least a little while+ok to mess around with friends+can customize your character+can make your own challangesI would give this a 7/10 at most, to say this is the "legendary snowboarding of our dreams" is sad and even scary, THIS is the best snow boarding games have to offer? geeeeeeez.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Even though this game wasn't for me, that doesn't mean it's not for you. If you're you looking for an action packed time of bombing down the mountain as fast as you can with your friends, this could be for you. Personally, I care more about putting together solid lines of tricks and that simply isn't possible in this game. (Even after turning off the "Fun Stopper Setting" which prevents you from doing tricks when you don't have enough air time to do.) This game feels like it doesn't want you to do the same trick twice. I felt like I was battling the controlls to put together consistent runs through a park section. I get that it isn't supposed to be a simulation game but the level of control, even for an arcadey game  just isn't there.I have been playing SNOW for a few years now and that has percise controlls and you feel like you are actually learning and getting better at the game when you put in the time to perfect a run through the park. With Steep, you can do the same exact input twice in a row and the game can give you two random outputs.Pros:Entire map is available right awayFeeling of speed is spot on regardless of sportDrop in, persistant multiplayerMeh:GraphicsMicrotransactions (are needed to enjoy the game, but they are present)Cons:Trick controlls are iffy at best3 additional sport types are locked unless you but a season pass...After a few hours it gets stale (unless you are into improving all of your challenge times and beating your friends)I had my purchase refunded, for me the price wasn't justified for the little bit of fun I was having. I may check it out again in the future when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: March 14
												what can I say? Its practically Shaun Whites surf boating with updated textures and levels. Besides the awkward jump button and laggy input response its a pretty okay game. The reasons I would not recommend this game include the sad G Force mechanic, the input lag, the overall buggy terrain, the slight luck factor and its lame music. The G Force mechanic is your biggest enemy in this game. It adds an unnecessary realism to the game that sometimes gets too real when you are going for the quad front off a cliff side with 4 seconds hang time. The best part is when you are carving at a reasonable speed and hit a hidden lip causing you to catch slight air, do a 90 degree spin resulting in a topped out meter.Lets talk about the input lag. This mainly concerns the jump button. When approaching the lip of a jump you may hit another one of those tiny hidden jumps which causes your preloaded jump to cancel out. This leaves you riding of the main lip without any hang time and can really grind you gears. This occurs quite often. Another input lag issue regards flips and spins. I believe a month into the games release they apparently fixed flips and spins. On its first month of release you flipped or spun by flicking the stick right after you released jump. Once you figured that out things got fairly consistent. After the update they changed the flip and spin controls so that you could flick yo stick almost any time around jump release. The problem now is that its somehow less consistent as it was before. Now when you go for that quad frontflip off a big ole cliff you may end doing a single flip at an extremely slow rate. Very steezy looking, but not really good for racking up points.The terrain is A+ in this game. Gorgeous and realistic as all hell. The main issue with it is that it can get rather buggy sometimes. It mostly has to do with structural terrain. You will be mobbin at a jump, preload jump button, hit the bottom of transistion and all of a sudden half your speed disapears, you release jump and do 1.5 flips and land right on your face. If you have ever hit steep transistion in real life wether on a skateboard, bike or skiboard, you know you have to do a little hop  while transistioning in order to retain most of your speed. Unfortunately the game nor you (with jump) can accomplish this resulting in a lousy jump. When flying down a mountain it can sometimes be hard to spot small relief. If you are turning at high speed and manage to catch air off of it you will spin and you will goof up your clean g force meter if you manage to ride it out. Its like in real life. Almost as real as doing a quad fronty off a large cliff side.The luck factor is strong with this game. Expect to retry some challanges hundreds of times. This is mainly due to reasons listed above. Your multiplier is not easy to earn and will go away with any wipeout. wiping out due to reasons listed above  is common even with your taller than dad "vidya game skill level".The music is pretty lame. Feels like you are in a modern Disney movie. Where is DIO? Why no Jay zed? No Bhi Bhiman? They have included an option to turn off copyright music. This option is gauranteed to play some tunes you have never heard before but the selection seems microscopic. If you purchase this game and manage to hit Play, expect to become a slave to it. My "Y" button on my wired Xbox controller has been squished thousands of times from constantly retrying challenges. Thanks for reading. Add me if you want to master debate about this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 20 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												"Ride a massive open world of the Alps and ALASKA, where the powder is always fresh and the run never ends. Defy and master the world’s most epic mountains on skis, wingsuit, snowboard, and in paraglide." So I bought this game on the premise that I would be able to ski the Alps and Alaska because you know, thats what the store page says. So after playing for a few hours on the Alps I decided I wanted to check out Alaska. Hmmm, weird I cant find it anywhere. Maybe I have to reach level 25 to unlock it. Ok great! Just got to level 25, lets see what new stuff I can do now! Wait, I can't find Alaska or anything else new to do. This isnt right. Lets investigate. Upon checking reddit for Steep, because of course the Ubisoft website says the same thing the steep website does, which is nothing about future release. But I find out Alaska is going to be released shortly after release and is not included in game. Hmm, thats weird I could have sworn the store page that I gave $60 to said I could "Ride a massive open world of the Alps and Alaska, where the powder is always fresh and the run never ends. Defy and master the world’s most epic mountains on skis, wingsuit, snowboard, and in paraglide." But actually its only the Alps right now.So cool whatever I can wait a week or two. 2 months later finally a word is spoken about Alaska DLC. Feb 10th they say, everyone can enjoy the free DLC. But wait, come Feb 9th they announce "oh our bad its not perfect yet so we are delaying it another 2 weeks". Ok now it's getting a little ridiculous. You state on your page I can get Alaska but I don't. You build all this crazy hype for 2 months then give a concrete date to only say the DAY before release, you're delaying it another two weeks. Not cool. The game itself had huge potential. Obviously with my 36 hours of gameplay I enjoy the heck out of it which is why I am so frustrated to be misled this way. But the way the communication has been and with the amount of bugs that still exist plus the wacky scoring system in place, its tough to recommend this game especially at the $60 price tag that does not include everything that is listed on the page that says it is supposed to come with.

It is a great looking game and i wanted it so badly to be a mix between Amped 3 and SSX. But instead i got a remake of Epyx Winter Games.5/10.

												The more I played this game, the more unresponsive the controls were. At one point, while wing-suiting, I was holding back on the left stick, and my character just stopped responding entirely.This game could be amazing, if it only worked. Seriously, as I crept up to the 2 hours playtime mark, it felt like all the controls just went to♥♥♥♥♥♥ I couldn't even complete missions labeled "easy". The first thing I did in the game though, was teleport to a buddy of mine (who was on a platform designed for wing suits) and I proceeded to snowboard off that ramp, do a double backflip, and then shred halfway down the mountain. Some time later, and my character couldn't even jump over the edge of the platform. Unless there is a hidden mechanic for brain damage that prevents the player's inputs from working correctly, this game is flawed in the worst kind of way. Makes it almost seem like the game breaks slowly over time, so that it makes it harder to refund on Steam. Ubisoft is known for their shady work practices...

number of helpful: 4 of 23 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												♥♥♥♥♥controls, a meaningless story, and the most laughable excuse for a tutorial I've ever seen. Start game = Start Uplay a few times before the game will ever begin to start starting.Once in you start on top of a slope ready 2 shred. Unless you're like me in which case it's straight to the settings to make it stop playing at 800x600 on your 4k display.Most people I've seen have been comparing this to Skate and I can see why. The game feels very much like that emptyish world made just for you to play in. However Skates controls and mechanics were tight and responsive. ♥♥♥♥ing up meant you did a bad not the game. This game has none of that. It's the kind of thing where when pushing entirely left or right theres only a chance your character will listen. Nothing you do matters because at any point in time your character may just decide he likes that tree/rock.In the looks department this game is glory. It shines and damn near makes up for the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Half of the time I would end up focusing more on the environment than I did the player model because trying to land tricks is just such a hassle. Though I do definitely feel like if you spent to long playing everything would probably start pretty samey, due in part to the somewhat small(er than you'd expect) map. All in all the game is ok. It's the kind of thing where if you can push past the ♥♥♥♥ awful controls I'm sure you could have a nice time. But at the same time be very ready to occasionally get stuck and unable to turn your board. Also similar to how the other three sports feel I'm gonna tack this last bit on. The skiing, paragliding, and squirrel suit are all pretty lack luster and control just as lame. Paragliding though? I don't even know how to get points! The tricks seemed mostly like swinging so??? I guess?Tl;Dr If you want to enjoy some pretty good views, don't care about Uplay, don't mind having little to no control at many many points, and really enjoy tiny snowballs flicking up from your board to tumble through the snow (don't worry I love it too) go for it on sale. I still ended up heading for the refund.

content:
Posted: February 3
												This game ♥♥♥♥ing sucks because of the poorly developed control, animation and depth of action given to paragliding and wingsuiting. Adjusting altitude/speed with the wingsuit is nauseating and could easily have been given a much smoother, closer-to-reality feel.It also sucks because the map is incredibly difficult to navigate. With practice it might feel more natural but that's not part of the game that should have a learning curve.It also sucks because it is difficult to find an event that the obnoxious voice is telling you about. Also something that once learned may be easier but ridiculous that it's a road block to entry level play.Put 6 hours into the game, love mountains and exploring. Maybe my tendency to actually go outside has biased my view of the game, but I found it to be incredibly frustrating and NOT, as other reviewers have put it, good for "relaxing or chilling".
